Snow, producing heavy accumulations, was accompanied by winds gusting over 40 mph. The snow began early on March 1st after a brief respite from the previous snowfall, with winds increasing as the day went on. Blizzard conditions with widespread near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow resulted. Roads were blocked by drifting and travel was made impossible or extremely difficult. Interstate 90 was closed during the storm. Numerous businesses and schools were forced to close, and school athletic events and other activities were cancelled. Of those who did attempt to travel during the storm, several vehicles were stranded and others slid off roads. There were several power outages. The weight of the heavy snow and the winds caused several machine shed roofs to collapse in the Tyler to Marshall area, with some machinery damage resulting. The blizzard followed another significant snow 1 to 2 days before. The snow decreased on the night of March 2nd, with blizzard conditions abating by early morning on March 3rd. New snow accumulations ranged from 8 to 16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: New snowfall of 10 to 16 inches beginning early morning on March 1st and continuing into the night of March 2nd was accompanied by sustained winds of over 30 mph at times with gusts over 40 mph. The combination of new snow, wind, and an already existing fresh snow cover resulted in a blizzard with widespread near zero visibilities. Drifting snow with the storm helped make travel impossible to extremely difficult. As a result, some who did attempt to travel became stuck or slid off roads. Schools and school activities were cancelled and numerous businesses closed. Power outages were reported as the heavy snow and strong winds brought down power lines. The blizzard conditions abated early on the morning of March 3rd.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the evening of the 17th, an area of surface low pressure was located just northeast of Jamestown, North Dakota, with a cold front extending south from the low. A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many large trees were snapped off or uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front encountered a warm...moist and unstable airmass over east-central Pennsylvania during the early afternoon. Thunderstorms developed rapidly and produced large hail ranging from nickel to baseball size and damaging winds. Large hail covered the ground in several locations. In addition, hail ripped siding off of homes, put holes in slate roofs, dented hundreds of cars and broke numerous windshields.  Lycoming county emergency management estimated between $300,000 to $400,000 dollars in hail damage. Although some storms exhibited strong rotational signatures and funnel clouds were sighted, no tornadoes were confirmed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported nickel sized hail covering the ground in Pennsdale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated low precipitation supercell initiated along the dryline over the extreme northern South Plains of west Texas during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 20th. The storm moved north-northeast across Swisher County, where it produced large hail between quarter and ping pong ball size along a swath from southwestern Swisher County to north of Tulia.

An upper jet over the northern plains helped to enhance snow development with this system. At the surface, a weak area of low pressure tracked from north central Nebraska into southern Wisconsin, while an inverted trough extended up to the north. This brought about a 12 hour period of heavy snow, followed by gusty north northwest winds (on the 3rd). Numerous schools and activities closed across the area on Tuesday (3rd). Many vehicles were reported in the ditch, especially along Interstate 94 between Moorhead and Fergus Falls. 10 inches of snow was reported at Norcross, 9 inches near Battle Lake, and 7 inches at Ponsford, Wadena, and Wendell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prefrontal trough moved across Michigan producing storms that layed out several outflow boundaries that progressed south into northwestern Ohio. These boundaries interacted with a high CAPE/low shear environment to set the stage for pulse thunderstorms. Several wet microbursts developed and produced areas of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 18 inch diameter tree was uprooted, falling onto a house, causing roof damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low level jet, remnants of a morning complex of storms from Iowa, and increasing instability all combined to create favorable conditions for damaging winds and isolated supercells. One supercell in particular had a storm motion towards the southeast when the line it was associated with moved mainly eastward. This supercell did produce a tornado in Marshall county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and tree limbs were blown down onto two mobile homes and a house, as well as several local roads. Damage is estimated at $25,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and upper level disturbance moved across the  central and eastern counties in the Billings County Warning Area during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 13th. Several thunderstorms developed across Northern Stillwater and Sweet Grass Counties before evolving into Supercell thunderstorms over Northern Yellowstone County. These thunderstorms then merged into a squall line across Eastern Yellowstone County and Treasure County before moving across Rosebud, Custer and Fallon Counties. Very large hail and damaging winds accompanied these thunderstorms with widespread damage reported across these areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of Extratropical Storm Noel tracking up off the Mid Atlantic Coast and High Pressure building into the region from the northwest produced strong northeast winds over portions of the Lower Maryland Eastern Shore.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust of 51 mph was measured at 44009. Wind gust of 40 mph was measured at OXB.

CZ_NAME: WEST JACKSON & WEST GRAND COUNTIES ABOVE 9000 FEET
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system brought moderate to heavy snowfall to the North-Central Mountains as well as to areas in and near the Front Range Foothills.  Storm totals included:  11.5 inches at the Tower Snotel, 8 inches; 4 miles west-southwest of Eldorado Springs, 7.5 inches; 3 miles west of Jamestown, 7 inches; 7 miles east-northeast of Red Feather Lakes at Roach Snotel, with 6 inches observed at Bear Lake National Park, 1 mile north of Bergen Park, 3 miles southwest of Conifer, Pinewood Lake and Winter Park.  Along the Urban Corridor there were some locally higher amounts reported near the foothills of Boulder and Larimer Counties.  Storm totals in those areas included:  7 inches; 3 miles south-southeast of Fort Collins with 6 inches observed in Boulder and at Horsetooth Inlet Bay.  Elsewhere across the Urban Corridor, storm totals ranged from 2 to 5 inches.

Several bouts of heavy snow during March 2007 helped ease the drought concerns over portions of northwest and west central Minnesota. Roseau, Lake of the Woods, North and South Beltrami, North Clearwater, and Hubbard counties began the month in a D3 (extreme) drought designation (per the U.S. Drought Monitor). East Marshall, Pennington, South Clearwater, Wadena, Red Lake, East Polk, Mahnomen, and East Becker began the month in a D2 (severe) drought designation. On April 3rd, Lake of the Woods and North Beltrami counties were downgraded from a D3 to a D2 designation. All the other counties mentioned above were dropped below a D2 designation.

Late in the afternoon of the 9th, a cold front was located just to the north of the Canadian border (across southern Saskatchewan, southern Manitoba, and southwestern Ontario). Temperatures at 500 millibars were quite cold. As temperatures warmed at the surface and an upper level disturbance moved through, thunderstorms were able to form and intensify enough to produce hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail fell near the Polk and Red Lake County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front had been located along a Roseau (Minnesota) to Grand Forks (North Dakota) line around midday. This boundary essentially washed out by late afternoon. However, showers and thunderstorms continued along the boundary for most of the day, and one stronger cell formed by late afternoon. This thunderstorm cell produced the tornado and funnel cloud reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Muliple brief waterspouts were observed near Peterson Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of surface low pressure was located near Mobridge, South Dakota, early in the morning hours of the 17th. A warm front extended to the east from the low, into eastern South Dakota and southern Minnesota. As the low level jet intensified in the late evening, storms began to take shape south of Bismarck. These storms then expanded to the east along the Interstate 94 corridor toward the Fargo-Moorhead area.

Thunderstorms rumbled across south-central Nebraska during the evening hours.  These storms produced some hail up to the size of golf balls and a few wind gusts to around 60 mph.  Inch and three-quarters diameter hail fell in Cozad and inch an a half diameter hail feel north of Loup City. Strong winds downed tree limbs around the Harlan County Dam.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding of streets, yards, and ditches.

Strong to severe thunderstorms formed in moist and unstable air in advance of a strong cold front that moved through the four state area during the afternoon and evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were blown down on the north side of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level storm system moved into the southern plains and lower mississippi valley during the morning and afternoon hours of the 24th. The atmosphere became very unstable ahead of this system as a dryline moved into southwest Arkansas during the late morning and afternoon hours. Severe thunderstorms developed rapidly in the ustable airmass and enough shear was present such that tornadoes developed across portions of southwest Arkansas.

Lake Effect snow bands developed across northern Herkimer and Hamilton counties during Monday, January 8th, and persisted across the region through Tuesday afternoon, on January 9th.  The snow bands then shifted south into southern Herkimer county from Tuesday night into Wednesday morning on January 10th.|The snow bands shifted south of the region by late afternoon on January 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Lake Effect snow band drifted south into southern Herkimer County during the late afternoon hours of Tuesday January 9th, and persisted until Wednesday morning, January 10th, when the snow bands shifted to the south and weakened.|Isolated total snowfall amounts of 7 to 9 inches occurred within this band, with 8.5 inches reported at Grant.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Lake Effect snow band developed across northern Herkimer county during the afternoon hours of Wednesday January 31st, and persisted into the late evening hours, before shifting north of the region.|Total snowfall accumulations of 8 to 11 inches occurred within the most intense and persistent portion of the snow band, with 11 inches reported at Old Forge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly settled south across the region late Saturday, January 13th, before becoming stationary across the northern Mid Atlantic states. A wave of low pressure then traveled northeast along this front, and produced a mix of freezing rain and sleet across the region Sunday morning.

A wave of low pressure then traveled northeast along this front, and produced a mix of freezing rain and sleet across the region Sunday morning.|Ice accretion of a few hundredths of an inch, up to two tenths of an inch occurred during Sunday morning, producing hazarous travel conditions.|The freezing rain changed to plain rain and drizzle around noontime, as temperatures warmed above freezing.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero, with some temperatures as low as 15 degrees below zero across higher elevations of the Adirondacks.|In addition, northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chills as low as 25 to 30 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero, with some temperatures as low as 15 degrees below zero across higher elevations of the Adirondacks. |The coldest temperature recorded in southern Fulton county was 12 degrees below zero in Gloversville.|In addition, northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chills as low as 15 to 25 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system moved eastward out of north Texas during the morning of June 3rd and intensified as it moved into northeast Texas.  This system was embedded in northwesterly winds aloft which are often prolific wind producers if these systems can sustain themselves.  The storm system encountered a very unstable airmass across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  The result was widespread wind damage across the southern half of northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana through the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees downed along with power lines across the entire parish.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed in an unstable airmass near a warm frontal boundary across western Pennsylvania. Storms produced locally heavy rainfall and nickel sized hail in Cambria county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported nickel size hail 2 miles southeast of Cherry Tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused isolated Flash Flooding in Cambria County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential rain from thunderstorms triggered a rock slide in Ferndale Borough along Plainfield Avenue. Flash Flooding was also noted along Berkley Road in Upper Yoder Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary across southwest Pennsylvania provided the focus for heavy rain and thunderstorms which produced isolated flash flooding in Cambria County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding which resulted in the closure of Route 22 one mile west of Portage exit. Several basements were also flooded in Conemaugh Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorm complexes moved over Cambria County, causing flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A series of slow moving thunderstorms caused flash flooding in the Nanty Glo area. Numerous roads were flooded between Nanty Glo and Twin Rocks, with additional road flooding reported in Blacklick Township. The north branch of Blacklick Creek also came out of it's banks, flooding Route 422, Route 271 and numerous other local roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of thunderstorm complexes moved over Cambria County, causing flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains caused flooding and closure of numerous roads near Wilmore and Portage. Numerous reports of basement flooding were also received near Wilmore.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary thunderstorm caused isolated flash flooding in Tioga County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrential thunderstorm rains of up to 2 inches in an hour caused the flooding the northbound lanes of Route 15 about 2 miles south of Blossburg in Tioga County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fairly widespread dense fog developed across north central and central portions of Kansas during the morning hours of August 25th.  Calm winds and an exceptionally moist boundary layer combined to promote fog development.

Late in the evening of the 17th, an area of surface low pressure was located just northeast of Jamestown, North Dakota, with a cold front extending south from the low. A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many large trees and tree branches were blown down by the strong wind. Boats, boat lifts, roofs, and docks were damaged. One cabin on Maple Lake had its windows broken and a wall bowed in.

Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roof and tree damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front encountered a very warm and unstable atmosphere which resulted in scattered severe pulse-type storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported trees down in Clinton Township on Route 405 between Muncy and Montgomery.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front encountered a very warm and unstable atmosphere which resulted in scattered severe pulse-type storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lycoming county emergency manager reported trees and wires down in Muncy and Muncy Creek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front encountered a very warm and unstable atmosphere which resulted in scattered severe pulse-type storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Adams county 911 center reported trees down in New Oxford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak cold front encountered a very warm and unstable atmosphere which resulted in scattered severe pulse-type storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotter reported trees and power lines down in Hanover.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front encountered a warm...moist and unstable airmass over east-central Pennsylvania during the early afternoon. Thunderstorms developed rapidly and produced large hail ranging from nickel to baseball size and damaging winds. Large hail covered the ground in several locations. In addition, hail ripped siding off of homes, put holes in slate roofs, dented hundreds of cars and broke numerous windshields.  Lycoming county emergency management estimated between $300,000 to $400,000 dollars in hail damage. Although some storms exhibited strong rotational signatures and funnel clouds were sighted, no tornadoes were confirmed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public measured hail the size of a ping-pong ball. The hail had been on the ground for 30 minutes before measurement.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several bouts of heavy snow during March 2007 helped ease the drought concerns over portions of northwest and west central Minnesota. Roseau, Lake of the Woods, North and South Beltrami, North Clearwater, and Hubbard counties began the month in a D3 (extreme) drought designation (per the U.S. Drought Monitor). East Marshall, Pennington, South Clearwater, Wadena, Red Lake, East Polk, Mahnomen, and East Becker began the month in a D2 (severe) drought designation. On April 3rd, Lake of the Woods and North Beltrami counties were downgraded from a D3 to a D2 designation. All the other counties mentioned above were dropped below a D2 designation.

On April 3rd, Lake of the Woods and North Beltrami counties were downgraded from a D3 to a D2 designation. All the other counties mentioned above were dropped below a D2 designation.

A surface low tracked from southwest Minnesota into northern Wisconsin, while an inverted trough set up across northwest Minnesota. This brought about a 12 hour period of heavy snow in a band from Roseau to Red Lake Falls, where 6 to 6.5 inches of snow was reported.

A surface low tracked from southwest Minnesota into northern Wisconsin, while an inverted trough set up across northwest Minnesota. This brought about a 12 hour period of heavy snow in a band from Roseau to Red Lake Falls, where 6 to 6.5 inches of snow was reported.

An upper jet over the northern plains helped to enhance snow development with this system. At the surface, a weak area of low pressure tracked from north central Nebraska into southern Wisconsin, while an inverted trough extended up to the north. This brought about a 12 hour period of heavy snow, followed by gusty north northwest winds (on the 3rd). Numerous schools and activities closed across the area on Tuesday (3rd). Many vehicles were reported in the ditch, especially along Interstate 94 between Moorhead and Fergus Falls. 10 inches of snow was reported at Norcross, 9 inches near Battle Lake, and 7 inches at Ponsford, Wadena, and Wendell.

In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone  thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rain accompanied the hail.

Warm and humid conditions as well as a weak flow aloft set the stage for thunderstorms to develop as numerous boundaries interacted. Isolated severe weather was reported parts of Northern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A semi truck was blown over on Interstate 469, southwest of Fort Wayne. Several trees were blown down, as well as part of a barn roof being blown off. A 71 mph wind gust was recorded at the Fort Wayne International Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable atmosphere combined with several subtle boundaries allowed for pulse thunderstorm development across northern Indiana. A few of these storms produced locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of trees and power lines down were received across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable atmosphere combined with several subtle boundaries allowed for pulse thunderstorm development across northern Indiana. A few of these storms produced locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 20 inch tree was blown over into a house just north of Logansport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable atmosphere combined with several subtle boundaries allowed for pulse thunderstorm development across northern Indiana. A few of these storms produced locally damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down in the city of Rochester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the late evening into the overnight hours. A cloud to ground strike caused injuries to some teenagers attending a concert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four teenagers were camping at a music festival at a local college and sought shelter under a tree, which was struck by lightning. The teeneages were indirectly injured from the strike. They ranged in age from 14 to 19. Two were admitted to a local hospital in fair conditions, with the other two being treated and released.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of deep moisture and slow movement of storms resulted in flash flooding in some parts of extreme southwestern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several vehicles were stalled on roads throughout county, with water  from curb to curb in several areas. Three basements were reported flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and upper level disturbance moved across the  central and eastern counties in the Billings County Warning Area during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 13th. Several thunderstorms developed across Northern Stillwater and Sweet Grass Counties before evolving into Supercell thunderstorms over Northern Yellowstone County. These thunderstorms then merged into a squall line across Eastern Yellowstone County and Treasure County before moving across Rosebud, Custer and Fallon Counties. Very large hail and damaging winds accompanied these thunderstorms with widespread damage reported across these areas.

Several thunderstorms developed across Northern Stillwater and Sweet Grass Counties before evolving into Supercell thunderstorms over Northern Yellowstone County. These thunderstorms then merged into a squall line across Eastern Yellowstone County and Treasure County before moving across Rosebud, Custer and Fallon Counties. Very large hail and damaging winds accompanied these thunderstorms with widespread damage reported across these areas.

Around 3 pm CST, a fairly strong cold front was located along a line from Devils Lake, ND, to Hallock, MN. Throughout the evening, this cold front slowly sagged southward. By 6 pm CST, the front had reached a line from New Rockford, ND, to Roseau, MN. At this time, Jamestown, ND, reported a temperature of 86 degrees, while Devils Lake had dropped to 66 degrees. By midnight, the front was located along a line from Bemidji (MN) to Fargo (ND) to 20 miles south of Jamestown (ND). Behind the front, the temperature dropped to 39 degrees in Devils Lake a couple hours after midnight. Large hail, tornadoes, and flash flooding occurred during this event.

Around 3 pm CST, a fairly strong cold front was located along a line from Devils Lake, ND, to Hallock, MN. Throughout the evening, this cold front slowly sagged southward. By 6 pm CST, the front had reached a line from New Rockford, ND, to Roseau, MN. At this time, Jamestown, ND, reported a temperature of 86 degrees, while Devils Lake had dropped to 66 degrees. By midnight, the front was located along a line from Bemidji (MN) to Fargo (ND) to 20 miles south of Jamestown (ND). Behind the front, the temperature dropped to 39 degrees in Devils Lake a couple hours after midnight. Large hail, tornadoes, and flash flooding occurred during this event.

A band of showers and thunderstorms moved across western and central North Dakota, then stalled as they reached southeast North Dakota and portions of northwest Minnesota. Although the rainfall did thin out several times, it fell nearly continuously over this same area from the 13th through the 14th. An estimated 2 to 5 inches of rain fell over northeast Sargent County, southeast Ransom County, and northwest Richland County during this period. Flooding also occurred across these three counties earlier in June. Due to damages sustained during the two flood events, the three counties received a Presidential Disaster Declaration.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rural roads were flooded by the steady rain. For both June flood events, the Ransom County Emergency Manager reported 34,000 acres of washed out crops and $300,000 in road damages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of showers and thunderstorms moved across western and central North Dakota, then stalled as they reached southeast North Dakota and portions of northwest Minnesota. Flooding also occurred across these three counties earlier in June. Due to damages sustained during the two flood events, the three counties received a Presidential Disaster Declaration.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rural roads were closed due to the heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: By noon on the 7th, a surface low was located near Lake Park, Minnesota, with a trailing cold front extending back into extreme southeast North Dakota. An occluded front also extended to the northeast, toward the Bemidji, MN, area. Surface dew points pooled right around 60 F in the vicinity of the surface low with temperatures in the middle 70s. The cold front was strong for early June, with a noon temperature in Devils Lake, ND, of 48 degrees. This set up a strong surface thermal and moisture boundary along a Wahpeton-Breckenridge to Bemidji line. Storms initially fired across southeast ND and then spread into portions of west central and northwest MN. There was also strong upper level support for these storms, as one severe report north of Embden (in Cass County, ND) occurred well behind the surface boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters at the Indian Health Service observed a garbage bag spiral into the updraft area of the storm, but no touchdown or damage occurred.

Deeper moisture in the low layers of the atmosphere surged north from the central plains, on a strengthening low level jet. Thunderstorms developed over eastern South Dakota and west central Minnesota and lifted north.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous 8 to 10 inch diameter tree branches were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a prefrontal outflow boundary drapped across northern Indiana and a MCV from overnight convection across Nebraska the night before provided the focus for convection to develop. In addition, unstable conditions develop during the late morning and early afternoon with SBCAPES of 1500 to 2500 j/kg. Storms began to develop on this boundary during the mid afternoon hours and rapidly became severe across Indiana. A line of storms associated with the MCV and an approaching trough moved across the northern part of Indiana and into extreme southern Michigan. This line evolved into several small bowing segments which produced numerous reports of damaging winds, especially across parts of St Joseph county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were blown down across the southeast part of the county.

An arctic airmass the first two weeks of February resulted in sub-freezing temperatures, both for daily highs and lows.  The cold spell was followed by a rapid warm-up and resulted in ice jams and flooding across south-central Nebraska.  Ice jam flooding began on February 20th and lasted until February 27th. Flooding affected the Cedar River, Mud Creek, Sappa Creek, Wood River, Loup River, and the North, South and Middle Loup River branches.  Due to the ice jams, water overflowed the banks of the rivers and caused low land flooding. Water flowed over the Burlington Northern railroad tracks and state highway 2 between Ravenna and Sweetwater near the confluence of the Mud Creek and the South Loup River. Water also affected county roads adjacent to the rivers and creeks.

Scattered thunderstorms developed just west of the Hastings CWA. One storm entered extreme western Dawson County and produced hail and one tornado.  The tornado started south of Gothenburg and moved north. It crossed Interstate 80 where several vehicles and semis were blown off the road with several injuries reported, thankfully, none serious. At one farmstead, the twister killed nearly a dozen head of cattle. The tornado damaged or destroyed many outbuildings and farmhouses. The storm survey team rated this tornado as an EF2 based on damage to a farmhouse (FR12) that lost half of its roof and had many windows blown out (DOD6). This would have had an expected wind speed around 114 mph. Many wood utility poles (ETL) were also broken off at their base or snapped in half (DOD4). This would have an expected wind speed of 120 mph. The tornado had a maximum width around 3/4 mile about 5 miles north of Gothenburg. The storm also produced hail along its path in which the largest was softball in size.

Scattered thunderstorms developed just west of the Hastings CWA. One storm entered extreme western Dawson County and produced hail and one tornado.  The tornado started south of Gothenburg and moved north. It crossed Interstate 80 where several vehicles and semis were blown off the road with several injuries reported, thankfully, none serious. At one farmstead, the twister killed nearly a dozen head of cattle. The tornado damaged or destroyed many outbuildings and farmhouses. The storm survey team rated this tornado as an EF2 based on damage to a farmhouse (FR12) that lost half of its roof and had many windows blown out (DOD6). This would have had an expected wind speed around 114 mph. Many wood utility poles (ETL) were also broken off at their base or snapped in half (DOD4). This would have an expected wind speed of 120 mph. The tornado had a maximum width around 3/4 mile about 5 miles north of Gothenburg. The storm also produced hail along its path in which the largest was softball in size.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down southwest of Gothenburg and traveled north. It crossed Interstate 80 and passed about 2 miles west of the town of Gothenburg. The twister continued to the north and crossed from Dawson County into Custer County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms moved across south-central Nebraska in the late afternoon and evening hours. These storms produced some dime to quarter sized hail and some good rains.
Scattered thunderstorms moved across south-central Nebraska in the late afternoon and evening hours. These storms produced some dime to quarter sized hail and some good rains.

A vigorous upper level storm system moved into the southern plains and lower mississippi valley during the morning and afternoon hours of the 24th. The atmosphere became very unstable ahead of this system as a dryline moved into southwest Arkansas during the late morning and afternoon hours. Severe thunderstorms developed rapidly in the ustable airmass and enough shear was present such that tornadoes developed across portions of southwest Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light poles and power lines were downed in the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level storm system moved into the southern plains and lower mississippi valley during the morning and afternoon hours of the 24th. The atmosphere became very unstable ahead of this system as a dryline moved into northwest and north central Louisiana during the late morning and afternoon hours. Severe thunderstorms developed rapidly in the ustable airmass and enough shear was present such that severe thunderstorms and tornadoes developed across portions of northern Louisiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damaging thunderstorm wind gusts caused extensive damage on the north northeast side of Bossier city near Hwy 80 and Industrial Drive. A portable building business lost a total of 14 storage buildings with some of the buildings suffering moderate to major damage. The roof was taken off a local lounge as well. Part of the debris was blown into an occupied vehicle at a local fast food restaurant but the occupants were not injured. A monetary damage amount was not available for this publication.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail reported on Caddo Lake.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system moved eastward out of north Texas during the morning of June 3rd and intensified as it moved into northeast Texas.  This system was embedded in northwesterly winds aloft which are often prolific wind producers if these systems can sustain themselves.  The storm system encountered a very unstable airmass across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  The result was widespread wind damage across the southern half of northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana through the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of trees and power lines down across the western portion of the parish.  Large trees blocking Hwy 84 near the Natchitoches/Winn parish line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Fairly widespread dense fog developed across north central and central portions of Kansas during the morning hours of August 25th.  Calm winds and an exceptionally moist boundary layer combined to promote fog development.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant blow down of trees occurred in Jackson County, 3-4 miles southeast of Buffalo Pass.  About 25 acres of trees were blown down.  The trees were either snapped off or uprooted, and mostly ranged in size from 1 to 2 feet in diameter.  The largest trees downed were Blue Spruce.
A weak cold front encountered a very warm and unstable atmosphere which resulted in scattered severe pulse-type storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: York county Law enforcement reported roof damage and a large tree down in Hanover.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large thunderstorm complex /MCS/ produced isolated wind damage and torrential rainfall across western and central Pennsylvania during the early morning hours. This event started during the late evening hours on the 7th and continued into the early morning hours on August 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Clearfield county emergency management reported trees down in Westover Borough in Chest Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero, with some temperatures as low as 15 degrees below zero across higher elevations of the Adirondacks.|In addition, northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chills as low as 25 to 30 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and five degrees below zero. |The coldest temperature recorded in western Columbia county was 2 degrees below zero in North Chatham.|In addition, northwest winds of 5 to 10 mph produced wind chills as low as 10 to 20 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low tracked from southwest Minnesota into northern Wisconsin, while an inverted trough set up across northwest Minnesota. This brought about a 12 hour period of heavy snow in a band from Roseau to Red Lake Falls, where 6 to 6.5 inches of snow was reported.

An upper jet over the northern plains helped to enhance snow development with this system. At the surface, a weak area of low pressure tracked from north central Nebraska into southern Wisconsin, while an inverted trough extended up to the north. This brought about a 12 hour period of heavy snow, followed by gusty north northwest winds (on the 3rd). Numerous schools and activities closed across the area on Tuesday (3rd). Many vehicles were reported in the ditch, especially along Interstate 29 between the South Dakota border and Fargo. 9 inches of snow was reported at Havana and 8.5 inches at Dwight.

Late in the evening of the 17th, an area of surface low pressure was located just northeast of Jamestown, North Dakota, with a cold front extending south from the low. A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone  thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The funnel cloud did not last long.

A stationary boundary was located across northwestern Ohio during the mid afternoon hours. As instability increased, numerous storms began to develop with many producing hail.
A stationary boundary was located across northwestern Ohio during the mid afternoon hours. As instability increased, numerous storms began to develop with many producing hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power poles were bent over across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a prefrontal outflow boundary drapped across northern Indiana and a MCV from overnight convection across Nebraska the night before provided the focus for convection to develop. In addition, unstable conditions develop during the late morning and early afternoon with SBCAPES of 1500 to 2500 j/kg. Storms began to develop on this boundary during the mid afternoon hours and rapidly became severe. A line of storms associated with the MCV and an approaching trough moved across the northern part of Indiana. This line evolved into several small bowing segments which produced numerous reports of damaging winds and isolated tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees, tree limbs, power lines and poles were blown down in and around the South Bend/Mishawaka area. A spire from the basilica on the Notre Dame campus was knocked off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prefrontal trough moved across Michigan producing storms that layed out several outflow boundaries that progressed south into Indiana. These boundaries interacted with a high CAPE/low shear environment to set the stage for pulse thunderstorms. Several wet microbursts developed and produced areas of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down across a road west of Markle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front and upper level disturbance moved across the  central and eastern counties in the Billings County Warning Area during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 13th. Several thunderstorms developed across Northern Stillwater and Sweet Grass Counties before evolving into Supercell thunderstorms over Northern Yellowstone County. These thunderstorms then merged into a squall line across Eastern Yellowstone County and Treasure County before moving across Rosebud, Custer and Fallon Counties. Very large hail and damaging winds accompanied these thunderstorms with widespread damage reported across these areas.

Around 3 pm CST, a fairly strong cold front was located along a line from Devils Lake, ND, to Hallock, MN. Throughout the evening, this cold front slowly sagged southward. By 6 pm CST, the front had reached a line from New Rockford, ND, to Roseau, MN. At this time, Jamestown, ND, reported a temperature of 86 degrees, while Devils Lake had dropped to 66 degrees. By midnight, the front was located along a line from Bemidji (MN) to Fargo (ND) to 20 miles south of Jamestown (ND). Behind the front, the temperature dropped to 39 degrees in Devils Lake a couple hours after midnight. Large hail, tornadoes, and flash flooding occurred during this event.

Behind the front, the temperature dropped to 39 degrees in Devils Lake a couple hours after midnight. Large hail, tornadoes, and flash flooding occurred during this event.

Three to six inches of rain fell over Ransom, Sargent, and western Richland counties over the 5th and 6th, resulting in a lot of long duration water problems. This event was preceded by flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Residents built a 2 foot high dike on the south edge of town to prevent an overflowing slough from spreading into town.

A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down in an open field to the south of county road 9, about 2 miles west of the sugar beet plant. A rope funnel persisted for about 3 minutes, with intermittent tornado touchdowns over about a 2 minute period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: By noon on the 7th, a surface low was located near Lake Park, Minnesota, with a trailing cold front extending back into extreme southeast North Dakota. An occluded front also extended to the northeast, toward the Bemidji, MN, area. Surface dew points pooled right around 60 F in the vicinity of the surface low with temperatures in the middle 70s. The cold front was strong for early June, with a noon temperature in Devils Lake, ND, of 48 degrees. This set up a strong surface thermal and moisture boundary along a Wahpeton-Breckenridge to Bemidji line. Storms initially fired across southeast ND and then spread into portions of west central and northwest MN. There was also strong upper level support for these storms, as one severe report north of Embden (in Cass County, ND) occurred well behind the surface boundary.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a prefrontal outflow boundary drapped across northern Indiana and a MCV from overnight convection across Nebraska the night before provided the focus for convection to develop. In addition, unstable conditions develop during the late morning and early afternoon with SBCAPES of 1500 to 2500 j/kg. Storms began to develop on this boundary during the mid afternoon hours and rapidly became severe across Indiana. A line of storms associated with the MCV and an approaching trough moved across the northern part of Indiana and into extreme southern Michigan. This line evolved into several small bowing segments which produced numerous reports of damaging winds, especially across parts of St Joseph county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued over most of interior and southwest Florida during November as the onset of the South Florida dry season is compounding long-term rainfall deficits across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The onset of the South Florida dry season in November has resulted in the continuation of the severe drought (D2) conditions across the region. November rainfall was below normal, and the level of Lake Okeechobee continued to set daily record lows of just over 10 feet above sea level.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued over most of interior and southwest Florida during November as the onset of the South Florida dry season is compounding long-term rainfall deficits across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The onset of the South Florida dry season in November has resulted in the continuation of the severe drought (D2) conditions across the region. November rainfall was below normal, and the level of Lake Okeechobee continued to set daily record lows of just over 10 feet above sea level.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened across portions of Collier County during November as the onset of the South Florida dry season is compounding long-term rainfall deficits across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dry November led to the reinstatement of severe drought conditions (D2) to northern Collier County. Naples has only received less than 70 percent of its normal annual rainfall, with similar values inland. Water levels are low, caused by the below normal rainfall and the record low level of  Lake Okeechobee which was at just over 10 feet above sea level.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass the first two weeks of February resulted in sub-freezing temperatures, both for daily highs and lows.  The cold spell was followed by a rapid warm-up and resulted in ice jams and flooding across south-central Nebraska.  Ice jam flooding began on February 20th and lasted until February 27th. Flooding affected the Cedar River, Mud Creek, Sappa Creek, Wood River, Loup River, and the North, South and Middle Loup River branches.  Due to the ice jams, water overflowed the banks of the rivers and caused low land flooding. Water flowed over the Burlington Northern railroad tracks and state highway 2 between Ravenna and Sweetwater near the confluence of the Mud Creek and the South Loup River. Water also affected county roads adjacent to the rivers and creeks.

Scattered thunderstorms moved across south-central Nebraska in the late afternoon and evening hours. These storms produced some dime to quarter sized hail and some good rains.

Light to moderate snow developed in areas from the Smokies to the lower French Broad valley during the early evening and continued into the early morning hours. By 3 AM, snowfall amounts of 1-3 inches were fairly uniform across the area. Snow continued through the pre-dawn hours in areas from the northern Smokies, through the Piegeon River gorge, to the lower French Broad valley and surrounding areas. By the time the snow tapered off to flurries during mid-morning, snowfall totals ranged from 2-4 inches in the valleys, including Waynesville, Marshall, and Mars Hill, to 4-6 inches across the higher elevations near the Tennessee border. Snow showers continued to produce sporadic light accumulations in the higher elevations through much of the day.

Light snow developed during the early evening across the northern mountains and continued through much of the overnight hours. By sunrise, snowfall totals of 1 to 3 inches had occurred. As snow showers continued to affect the northern mountains, heavy snowfall levels were finally reached shortly after sunrise. Accumulations generally ranged from 2-4 inches, although some higher elevation locations along the Tennessee border saw slightly higher totals.

Light to occasionally moderate snow developed across the mountainous areas away from the Tennessee border during the early evening and continued through the overnight hours. Snowfall totals ranged from 2-3 inches.

A vigorous upper level storm system moved into the southern plains and lower mississippi valley during the morning and afternoon hours of the 24th. The atmosphere became very unstable ahead of this system as a dryline moved into northwest and north central Louisiana during the late morning and afternoon hours. Severe thunderstorms developed rapidly in the ustable airmass and enough shear was present such that severe thunderstorms and tornadoes developed across portions of northern Louisiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees downed 5 miles east of Summerfield near Thurmon Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much like on 12th, increasing low level instability below a relative minimum in temperatures aloft created a rapid destabilization of the atmosphere during the afternoon and evening hours on June 13, 2007. The storm motion was northeast to southwest, which is unusual for summertime convection in Central PA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported nickel-sized hail in Jonestown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero, with some temperatures as low as 15 degrees below zero across higher elevations of the Adirondacks.|In addition, northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chills as low as 25 to 30 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero. |The coldest temperature recorded in western Columbia county was 7 degrees below zero in East Chatham.|In addition, northwest winds of 5 to 10 mph produced wind chills as low as 15 to 25 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into western Massachusetts late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero. |In addition, northwest winds of 5 to 10 mph produced wind chills as low as 20 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into western Massachusetts late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero.|The coldest temperature recorded in northern Berkshire county was 10 degrees below zero at Peru.|In addition, northwest winds of 5 to 10 mph produced wind chills as low as 25 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widely scattered strong to severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon as a weak frontal trough moved through the region.

Late in the evening of the 17th, an area of surface low pressure was located just northeast of Jamestown, North Dakota, with a cold front extending south from the low. A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone  thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prefrontal trough moved across Michigan producing storms that layed out several outflow boundaries that progressed south into Indiana. These boundaries interacted with a high CAPE/low shear environment to set the stage for pulse thunderstorms. Several wet microbursts developed and produced areas of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down onto power lines as well as a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions which started in July, persisted into August with dry lightning triggering numerous wild fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning events in August triggered wild fires in Flathead and Sanders Counties. One of the largest fires in Sanders County, the Chippy Creek burned 98,590 acres and destroyed one Out Building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions which started in July, persisted into August with dry lightning events triggering numerous wild fires in north central Idaho.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning triggered numerous wild fires in Idaho County in August. 115,937 acres burned. The Boundary Junction Fire near the Clearwater County border north of Highway 12, destroyed one Out Building with 4671 acres burned. The largest wild fire, the Rattlesnake near Dixie burned 76,112 acres with three Out Buildings destoyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions which started in July, persisted into August with dry lightning triggering numerous wild fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning events in August triggered wild fires in Flathead County. The Skyland Fire burned 26,312 acres and destroyed two Out Buildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions which started in July, persisted into August with dry lightning triggering numerous wild fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning events in August triggered wild fires in Sanders, Missoula and Lake Counties. The Black Cat Fire burned 11,758 acres and destroyed seven Out Buildings between Frenchtown and Missoula.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and dry conditions which started in July, persisted into August with dry lightning triggering numerous wild fires.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning events in August triggered wild fires in Missoula County. The Black Cat Fire burned 11,758 acres and destroyed seven Out Buildings between Frenchtown and Missoula.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Around 3 pm CST, a fairly strong cold front was located along a line from Devils Lake, ND, to Hallock, MN. Throughout the evening, this cold front slowly sagged southward. By 6 pm CST, the front had reached a line from New Rockford, ND, to Roseau, MN. At this time, Jamestown, ND, reported a temperature of 86 degrees, while Devils Lake had dropped to 66 degrees. By midnight, the front was located along a line from Bemidji (MN) to Fargo (ND) to 20 miles south of Jamestown (ND). Behind the front, the temperature dropped to 39 degrees in Devils Lake a couple hours after midnight. Large hail, tornadoes, and flash flooding occurred during this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low level jet, remnants of a morning complex of storms from Iowa, and increasing instability all combined to create favorable conditions for damaging winds and isolated supercells. One supercell in particular had a storm motion towards the southeast when the line it was associated with moved mainly eastward. This supercell did produce a tornado in Marshall county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and tree limbs were reported down in and around Rochester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable atmosphere and strong wind field was in place across much of the region in advance of a strong mid level wave. A cluster of storms with extreme damaging winds moved rapidly from Illinois into Indiana producing numerous reports of wind damage and isolated hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees down across the county including South Bend.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable atmosphere and strong wind field was in place across much of the region in advance of a strong mid level wave. A cluster of storms with extreme damaging winds moved rapidly from Illinois into Indiana producing numerous reports of wind damage and isolated hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local officials reported several trees down in the Shipshewana area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a prefrontal outflow boundary drapped across northern Indiana and a MCV from overnight convection across Nebraska the night before provided the focus for convection to develop. In addition, unstable conditions develop during the late morning and early afternoon with SBCAPES of 1500 to 2500 j/kg. Storms began to develop on this boundary during the mid afternoon hours and rapidly became severe. A line of storms associated with the MCV and an approaching trough moved across the northern part of Indiana. This line evolved into several small bowing segments which produced numerous reports of damaging winds and isolated tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local officials reported receiving scattered tree and power line damage across the central part of the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large trees were blown down in and around Crooked Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions worsened across portions of Collier County during November as the onset of the South Florida dry season is compounding long-term rainfall deficits across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dry November led to the reinstatement of severe drought conditions (D2) to northern Collier County. Naples has only received less than 70 percent of its normal annual rainfall, with similar values inland. Water levels are low, caused by the below normal rainfall and the record low level of  Lake Okeechobee which was at just over 10 feet above sea level.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers over the Atlantic coastal waters led to the formation of waterspouts over the waters of Miami-Dade and Broward counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Waterspout was sighted over southern Biscayne Bay by general public and observers at Homestead Air Reserve Base.

CZ_NAME: DEERFIELD BEACH TO OCEAN REEF FL
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers over the Atlantic coastal waters led to the formation of waterspouts over the waters of Miami-Dade and Broward counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Waterspout was observed about 3 to 7 miles offshore Hallandale Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several bouts of heavy snow during March 2007 helped ease the drought concerns over portions of northwest and west central Minnesota. Roseau, Lake of the Woods, North and South Beltrami, North Clearwater, and Hubbard counties began the month in a D3 (extreme) drought designation (per the U.S. Drought Monitor). East Marshall, Pennington, South Clearwater, Wadena, Red Lake, East Polk, Mahnomen, and East Becker began the month in a D2 (severe) drought designation. On April 3rd, Lake of the Woods and North Beltrami counties were downgraded from a D3 to a D2 designation. All the other counties mentioned above were dropped below a D2 designation.

A moderate and persistent northeast flow between a surface high over the Eastern seaboard and a cold front across south Florida produced high surf and high astronomical tides along the Northeast Florida coast which caused beach erosion and coastal flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 10:54 am, the Ponce de Leon Inlet NOS tide gauge measured a maximum tide level of 5.04 ft. This was about 1.18 ft above predicted values. At 12:54 pm, the St. Johns County Life Guard Station reported strong rip currents and breaker heights of 4 ft. Minor coastal flooding at low beach entrances at Fort Mantanzas Inland and Porpoise Point was reported. There was a lot of beach erosion along county beaches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and persistent east to northeast low level flow between Tropical Storm Noel south of the area and high pressure to the north produced high surf along the northeast Florida coast Nov. 1st-2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jacksonville Beach Life Guard Station reported breakers of 5 to 6 feet each morning with occasional breakers of 8 to 10 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and persistent east to northeast low level flow between Tropical Storm Noel south of the area and high pressure to the north produced high surf along the northeast Florida coast Nov. 1st-2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management reported surf at Flagler Beach of 4 to 5 feet with occasional 6 to 8 feet breakers. The winds were blowing from the east northeast around 30 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and persistent east to northeast low level flow between Tropical Storm Noel south of the area and high pressure to the north produced high surf along the northeast Florida coast Nov. 1st-2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported breaker heights of 4 to 6 feet at St. Augustine Beach with occasional 7 foot breakers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal band of convection moved across Northeast Florida during the early morning hours of December 16th before sunrise. There was about a week of near record high temperatures across the area in advance of this storm system, allowing for many days of pre-frontal instability to develop across the area.  There was also a strong 850 mb southwest jet around 55 knots which advected low level moisture and instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico overnight in advanced of the surface front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were down across the Meadowbrook Golf Course. The cost of tree removal was estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions developed during the afternoon of August 20th over eastern Nebraska as a warm front set up from central into southeast Nebraska by early afternoon.  Temperatures were in the 90s with dew points in the 70s south of the boundary.  A strong upper level disturbance that moved across the state helped trigger thunderstorm development by mid afternoon as it brought a wind shift of drier air eastward to meet the unstable conditions.  Severe thunderstorms quickly developed and they congealed into several bow echo type configurations as they tracked across both the Lincoln and Omaha metro areas and then into southwest Iowa.  Moderate amounts of wind damage was reported with the activity along with scattered large hail reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive night wind chill values fell to at least 20 below zero over most of northeast Nebraska.  Low temperatures fell to around 10 below zero and when combined with northwest winds around 10 mph...wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed over the county as low temperatures dropped to around 10 below zero combined with northwest winds around 10 mph.  These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around midnight through 1000 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system moved out of the southwestern U.S. and dropped heavy snow over a large part of eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Winds during the event were relatively light, which limited the blowing and drifting. The snow began mid to late Saturday afternoon, 1/20/07, picked up in intensity from late afternoon into early evening and then began ending south to north Sunday morning between 800 am and 1000 am. Heavier snow amounts from this storm across eastern Nebraska included...9 inches in Prague, 8 inches in Papillion, Boystown and Fairbury, 7 inches at Fremont, Gretna, Nebraska City, Raymond, Hickman, Wayne and Loretto. Across southwest Iowa heavier amounts included...6 inches in Sidney, Council Bluffs, Little Sioux, and Clarinda and between 5 and 6 at Onawa, Castana and Shenandoah.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The co-op observer in Sidney reported 6 inches of snow from this storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and behind a cold front that moved across eastern Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 14th.  Most of the severe thunderstorm activity was confined to southeast Nebraska, as the storms weakened as they moved northeast across east central Nebraska and into western Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to nickel size fell in the Waverly area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief pea to dime size hail was reported in Fairbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and behind a cold front that moved across eastern Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 14th.  Most of the severe thunderstorm activity was confined to southeast Nebraska, as the storms weakened as they moved northeast across east central Nebraska and into western Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds estimated at around 70 mph caused a semi truck to overturn on Interstate 80 near exit 366.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. The severe reports generally consisted of large hail.

For the second day in a row early morning thunderstorms dropped heavy rain over sections of northeast Nebraska.  The heavy rain brought 2 day totals, August 22nd and 23rd, to over 4 inches in places, including Norfolk where 4.34 inches of rain fell.  The thunderstorms developed north of a stationary front that had remained over sections of eastern Nebraska that morning and for several days prior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused Plum Creek to flood across county road link 20a and also several gravel roads in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second day in a row early morning thunderstorms dropped heavy rain over sections of northeast Nebraska.  The heavy rain brought 2 day totals, August 22nd and 23rd, to over 4 inches in places, including Norfolk where 4.34 inches of rain fell.  The thunderstorms developed north of a stationary front that had remained over sections of eastern Nebraska that morning and for several days prior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused flash flooding across the jct of Highways 9 and 16 near Pender.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values fell to 20 below to 30 below zero for the second consecutive night over western Iowa.  Low temperatures fell to 5 below to 15 below over the region as northwest winds around 10 mph persisted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures that fell to 5 below to 15 below and northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chill values that fell to 20 below to 25 below zero.  These cold wind chill readings prevailed from around 4 am through 1000 am before moderating slightly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values fell to 20 below to 30 below zero for the second consecutive night over western Iowa.  Low temperatures fell to 5 below to 15 below over the region as northwest winds around 10 mph persisted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures that fell to 5 below to 15 below and northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chill values that fell to 20 below to 25 below zero.  These cold wind chill readings prevailed from around 5 am through 1000 am before moderating slightly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values fell to 20 below to 30 below zero for the second consecutive night over western Iowa.  Low temperatures fell to 5 below to 15 below over the region as northwest winds around 10 mph persisted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures that fell to 5 below to 15 below and northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chill values that fell to 20 below to 25 below zero.  These cold wind chill readings prevailed from around 6 am through 9 am before moderating slightly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low lingered in the area for several days.  An unstable atmosphere helped kick off several rounds of showers and storms.  Boundaries helped focus rainfall totals over the same areas....leading to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two feet of water reported in front yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of thunderstorms moved into north Texas during the early morning hours, causing wind damage in several counties.  Storms redeveloped later in the afternoon.
A strong line of thunderstorms moved into north Texas during the early morning hours, causing wind damage in several counties.  Storms redeveloped later in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree blown down south of Antelope.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of thunderstorms moved into north Texas during the early morning hours, causing wind damage in several counties.  Storms redeveloped later in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front crossed the area and produced widespread severe weather across northeast Montana.  This was the biggest outbreak of severe weather during the month of May during at least the last 5 years.

Slow moving thunderstorms developed during the late morning and early afternoon hours of June 15th across portions of north central Louisiana.  These thunderstorms developed in a very unstable and moist airmass resulting in wind damage and flash flooding in Jackson and Winn parishes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines down around town resulting in numerous power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms developed during the late morning and early afternoon hours of June 15th across portions of north central Louisiana.  These thunderstorms developed in a very unstable and moist airmass resulting in wind damage and flash flooding in Jackson and Winn parishes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: US 167...LA 505 and multiple parish roads in the Garrs Mills community near the Jackson/Winn parish line were under water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the heating of the day across portions of northeast Texas. An isolated thunderstorm developed in eastern Bowie County and caused a lightning strike that hit a home west of Texarkana, Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a home west of town resulting in a house fire.  Moderate damage was reported.  No injuries reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong sea-breeze boundary moved quickly northward out of southeast Texas and southwest Louisiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th.  A strong line of thunderstorms developed along the leading edge of the boundary causing sporadic strong winds that downed a few trees and power lines across portions of northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  Cloud to ground lightning was very intense as well and lightning resulted in scattered power outages in southwest Arkansas and northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning destroyed a power pole and knocked down power lines at the 2900 block of Robertson Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flooding continued from several days of rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurred on the Interstate 35 service roads south of Valley View.  The roads had up to two feet of water across them.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low remained over the area triggering several rounds of showers and thunderstorms.  A very moist environment encouraged flash flooding on top of already saturated grounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A railroad train derailed after heavy rains caused portions of the track to wash out.  Four cars fell over and the line had to be shut down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low remained over the area triggering several rounds of showers and thunderstorms.  A very moist environment encouraged flash flooding on top of already saturated grounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A railroad had to shut down portions of its line through town due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low remained over the area triggering several rounds of showers and thunderstorms.  A very moist environment encouraged flash flooding on top of already saturated grounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CR 1229 and CR 1232 off of Highway 84 were flooded by Stills Creek due to heavy rains.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved across a portion of northeast Montana during the late evening of the 5th into the early morning hours of the 6th.
Severe thunderstorms affected a porion of northeast Montana during the afternoon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was accompanied by heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms affected a porion of northeast Montana during the afternoon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged in size from pea to penny.  A half inch of rain fell in 25 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms affected a porion of northeast Montana during the afternoon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged in size from pea to nickel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms affected a porion of northeast Montana during the afternoon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the hail was pea sized with some penny sized hail mixed in at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms continued to produce flood producing rainfall across portions of northeast Texas as well as northwest Louisiana on July 6th.  Moisture continued to feed northward from the Gulf of Mexico which fueled these thunderstorms once they developed.  The region continued to be in a favorable area for thunderstorm development as an upper level area of low pressure remained anchored across central and north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water across Hwy. 451 east of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms continued to produce flood producing rainfall across portions of northeast Texas as well as northwest Louisiana on July 6th.  Moisture continued to feed northward from the Gulf of Mexico which fueled these thunderstorms once they developed.  The region continued to be in a favorable area for thunderstorm development as an upper level area of low pressure remained anchored across central and north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hwy. 59 was closed in the city of Marshall, Texas due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front with strong dynamics and windshear pushed into the area late Saturday and early Sunday.  Hail and microbursts accompanied the first wave of storms while the second wave of storms produced a half dozen tornadoes.  The largest was an EF3 that killed on person and injured 3 others.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff reported trees down on Clarks Hill road near the Merryweather area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After one of the warmest March's on record, an unprecedented spell of cold weather hovered over the region between April 4th and April 10th. Low temperatures dropped into the upper teens and twenties. Trees and flowers which had budded or bloomed were extensively damaged. In addition...crop damage was extensive as well with many areas needing to be replanted. Most vineyards and fruit orchards had from 70 to 95 percent losses.
A cold front crossed the area and produced severe thunderstorms during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was accompanied by 40 to 50 mph wind and heavy rainfall.

An upper level low pressure system moving into west Texas interacted with a moist and unstable airmass over north Texas.  This resulted in large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mexia school police reported golfball-size hail on FM 2838.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of severe thunderstorms which developed earlier in the day across southern Oklahoma and north Texas...produced and outflow boundary which aided in the redevelopment of strong to severe convection across northeast Texas later in the day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down along county road 2011.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was three to four feet deep on Walker Street and on Elliott Street at South Dunegan.
