EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bow echo originated in northeast Texas during the evening hours of June 18th and transversed across southern Arkansas and northwest Louisiana.  This bow echo produce widespread wind damage throughout its path.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down west of town on county road 4101.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A bow echo originated in northeast Texas during the evening hours of June 18th and transversed across southern Arkansas and northwest Louisiana.  This bow echo produce widespread wind damage throughout its path.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed on Hwy. 59 south of Atlanta, Texas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front encountered a warm...moist and unstable airmass over east-central Pennsylvania during the early afternoon. Thunderstorms developed rapidly and produced large hail ranging from nickel to baseball size and damaging winds. Large hail covered the ground in several locations. In addition, hail ripped siding off of homes, put holes in slate roofs, dented hundreds of cars and broke numerous windshields.  Lycoming county emergency management estimated between $300,000 to $400,000 dollars in hail damage. Although some storms exhibited strong rotational signatures and funnel clouds were sighted, no tornadoes were confirmed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Schuylkill county law enforcement reported golf-ball sized hail in McAdoo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero, with some temperatures as low as 15 degrees below zero across higher elevations of the Adirondacks.|In addition, northwest winds of 10 to 15 mph produced wind chills as low as 25 to 30 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass moved into east central New York State late Thursday night on January 25th, and remained in place into Friday, January 26th. Early morning low temperatures on Friday ranged between zero and ten degrees below zero. |The coldest temperature recorded in western Albany county was 7 degrees below zero at Berne.|In addition, northwest winds of 5 to 10 mph produced wind chills as low as 10 to 20 degrees below zero early Friday morning, especially across higher elevations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed east across east central New York and western New England during the afternoon hours of Tuesday June 5th. The interaction of this strong front, combined with a warm, moist and unstable air mass in place, led to the development of strong to severe thunderstorms across eastern New York and western New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in Clifton Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front pushed east across east central New York and western New England during the afternoon hours of Tuesday June 5th. The interaction of this strong front, combined with a warm, moist and unstable air mass in place, led to the development of strong to severe thunderstorms across eastern New York and western New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported in Stillwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A pre-frontal band of convection moved across Northeast Florida during the early morning hours of December 16th before sunrise. There was about a week of near record high temperatures across the area in advance of this storm system, allowing for many days of pre-frontal instability to develop across the area.  There was also a strong 850 mb southwest jet around 55 knots which advected low level moisture and instability inland from the Gulf of Mexico overnight in advanced of the surface front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down across power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season snow developed over portions of central Virginia as a low pressure system deepened off the Delmarva Coast late April 6th. Snow showers began early on April 7th, with the heaviest snow falling between 2 and 6 AM. Snow amounts ranged from 1 to 4 inches, with highest amounts reported across Orange County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained Spotters reported 2 to 4 inches of snow from Orange to Barboursville, VA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed in the late afternoon hours across the Eastern Panhandle and Sandhills of Nebraska. A few of these storm were able to produce hail up to the size of quarters across Cherry and Grant counties.

Thunderstorms formed across the Southeast Nebraska Panhandle during the late afternoon hours and moved into the Western Sandhills region during the early evening hours. Hail ranging from quarter to golf-ball size was reported along with wind gusts near 60 mph.

For the second consecutive night wind chill values fell to at least 20 below zero over most of northeast Nebraska.  Low temperatures fell to around 10 below zero and when combined with northwest winds around 10 mph...wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed over the county as low temperatures dropped to around 10 below zero combined with northwest winds around 10 mph.  These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around 5 am until 10 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions developed during the afternoon of August 20th over eastern Nebraska as a warm front set up from central into southeast Nebraska by early afternoon.  Temperatures were in the 90s with dew points in the 70s south of the boundary.  A strong upper level disturbance that moved across the state helped trigger thunderstorm development by mid afternoon as it brought a wind shift of drier air eastward to meet the unstable conditions.  Severe thunderstorms quickly developed and they congealed into several bow echo type configurations as they tracked across both the Lincoln and Omaha metro areas and then into southwest Iowa.  Moderate amounts of wind damage was reported with the activity along with scattered large hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds spread from the Papillion area across Bellevue and Offutt AFB causing scattered tree damage and downed power lines.  A wind gust of 67 mph was measured at Offutt AFB at 752 pm CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions developed during the afternoon of August 20th over eastern Nebraska as a warm front set up from central into southeast Nebraska by early afternoon.  Temperatures were in the 90s with dew points in the 70s south of the boundary.  A strong upper level disturbance that moved across the state helped trigger thunderstorm development by mid afternoon as it brought a wind shift of drier air eastward to meet the unstable conditions.  Severe thunderstorms quickly developed and they congealed into several bow echo type configurations as they tracked across both the Lincoln and Omaha metro areas and then into southwest Iowa.  Moderate amounts of wind damage was reported with the activity along with scattered large hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 mph lasted for around 15 minutes southwest of Dorchester.  These strong winds downed numerous 4 to 6 inch tree limbs and caused some damage to a chimney.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through the mid south on its way into Southwest Virginia and Eastern Tennessee.  A large bow developed on the line late in the evening as it approached the Cumberland Plateau. Damage was predominantly created by straight line winds. However, an EF1 Tornado also developed on the Cumberland Plateau in Claiborne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball to quarter size hail fell near Norma.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm moved over the Omaha metro area during the early evening hours of August 23rd.  The storms produced marginally severe size hail from Papillion toward Offutt AFB and also over far south Omaha.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to penny size was reported from around Papillion to Offutt AFB.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm moved over the Omaha metro area during the early evening hours of August 23rd.  The storms produced marginally severe size hail from Papillion toward Offutt AFB and also over far south Omaha.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second day in a row early morning thunderstorms dropped heavy rain over sections of northeast Nebraska.  The heavy rain brought 2 day totals, August 22nd and 23rd, to over 4 inches in places, including Norfolk where 4.34 inches of rain fell.  The thunderstorms developed north of a stationary front that had remained over sections of eastern Nebraska that morning and for several days prior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several days of heavy rain caused Tracy Creek to flood some county roads from around Humphrey to near Creston.  A few other creeks in the area also flooded some farm fields and other county roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several days of heavy rain flooded some county roads along Sand Creek near Pilger.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air plunged into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa on north winds of 15 to 25 mph.  As temperatures fell to zero to 5 below during the early morning hours of January 30, 2007, wind chill readings fell to 20 below to 25 below over sections of northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North winds of 15 to 25 mph and temperatures that dropped a little below zero created wind chill readings that fell into the 20 below to 25 below zero range.  These cold wind chill values were observed across the area from around 2 am until 9 am before moderating slightly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of thunderstorms moved into north Texas during the early morning hours, causing wind damage in several counties.  Storms redeveloped later in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front crossed the area and produced widespread severe weather across northeast Montana.  This was the biggest outbreak of severe weather during the month of May during at least the last 5 years.

A strong cold front crossed the area and produced widespread severe weather across northeast Montana.  This was the biggest outbreak of severe weather during the month of May during at least the last 5 years.

A strong cold front crossed the area and produced widespread severe weather across northeast Montana.  This was the biggest outbreak of severe weather during the month of May during at least the last 5 years.

A strong sea-breeze boundary moved quickly northward out of southeast Texas and southwest Louisiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th.  A strong line of thunderstorms developed along the leading edge of the boundary causing sporadic strong winds that downed a few trees and power lines across portions of northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  Cloud to ground lightning was very intense as well and lightning resulted in scattered power outages in southwest Arkansas and northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree was downed along with four light poles along interstate 20 on the east side of Bossier City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Texas during the mid/late afternoon hours of the 27th, producing a large swath of tree, power line, and structural damage. These storms developed well ahead of a cold front that extended from southern and eastern Oklahoma, into central Arkansas, but mainly along a differential moisture boundary that moved south across east Texas, extreme southern Arkansas, and north Louisiana. Strong surface instability, and gust fronts that developed from these storms, focused new shower and thunderstorm development, with several of these storms becoming severe. One longer lived severe thunderstorm developed over eastern Upshur County, then merged with another southward moving band of strong thunderstorms, producing widespread wind damage across eastern Upshur, much of Gregg, and northern Rusk County. The cities of Longview and Kilgore were hit hardest, with numerous trees blown down/uprooted, power lines downed, and trees falling onto homes, with at least one known injury reported. A 53-yr old man was killed on the north side of Longview when lightning struck a tree he was standing near in wake of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down on CR 311 in the community of Melrose.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced hail in central Wibaux County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was accompanied by 1 inch of rain in 30 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall in excess of 3 inches across portions of northeast Montana on June 6th into the early morning hours of the 7th.  The heavy rain led to flash flooding and flooding of small streams and creeks.  The most significant flooding was in Prairie County where Interstate 94 was under a foot of water during the late evening/early morning hours along the Prairie/Custer County border. There were also reports of flooding along Timber and Cherry Creeks in Western Prairie County where fences were washed out and gravel roads had washouts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Interstate 94 was under a foot of water along the Prairie/Custer County border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rainfall in excess of 3 inches across portions of northeast Montana on June 6th into the early morning hours of the 7th.  The heavy rain led to flash flooding and flooding of small streams and creeks. There were also reports of flooding along Timber and Cherry Creeks in Western Prairie County where fences were washed out and gravel roads had washouts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three inches of rain was measured in an hour.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed during the heating of the day across portions of northeast Texas. An isolated thunderstorm developed in eastern Bowie County and caused a lightning strike that hit a home west of Texarkana, Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half a dozen trees were reported down across different portions of the county resulting in numerous power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds downed a few trees and power lines.  The Eastside Missionary Baptist Churck had a tin roof peeled back and deposited along Reynolds Street and into the parking lot of an adjacent church.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front with strong dynamics and windshear pushed into the area late Saturday and early Sunday.  Hail and microbursts accompanied the first wave of storms while the second wave of storms produced a half dozen tornadoes.  The largest was an EF3 that killed on person and injured 3 others.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff reported numerous trees down in and around the Bamberg area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms associated with a cold front, grazed the extreme northeastern portion of our CWA, during the afternoon hours of March 31st. Large hail was reported around Lancaster.
Heavy rains on March 30th caused Moniteau Creek near Fayette to exceed flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moniteau Creek near Fayette crested at 16.09 feet, or 0.09 feet above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and upper level storm system...combined to bring stormy conditions to west central Missouri on April 25th. Large hail and heavy rains with flash flooding were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Funnel cloud was observed near Merwin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and upper level storm system...combined to bring stormy conditions to west central Missouri on April 25th. Large hail and heavy rains with flash flooding were reported.
A cold front touched off a severe thunderstorm in northern Valley County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large border crossing sign was blown over by the strong wind.  The wind was accompanied by pea to penny size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level storm system and strong cold front produced a widespread severe weather outbreak in northeastern Montana.  The majority of the events were high wind, a few reports of large hail, and two tornadoes.

Showers and thunderstorms continued to produce flood producing rainfall across portions of northeast Texas as well as northwest Louisiana on July 6th. Moisture continued to feed northward from the Gulf of Mexico which fueled these thunderstorms once they developed. The region continued to be in a favorable area for thunderstorm development as an upper level area of low pressure remained anchored across central and north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Youree Drive at Southfield Road intersection is under several inches of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After one of the warmest March's on record, an unprecedented spell of cold weather hovered over the region between April 4th and April 10th. Low temperatures dropped into the upper teens and twenties. Trees and flowers which had budded or bloomed were extensively damaged. In addition...crop damage was extensive as well with many areas needing to be replanted. Most vineyards and fruit orchards had from 70 to 95 percent losses.

Additional heavy rainfall after a record wet May caused the Antelope Creek in southern Valley County to come out of it's banks during the early morning hours of the 1st.  The creek was overrunning portions of Billingsley Road.  The Tallow Creek in southern Phillips County also came out of it's banks and washed out a gravel road.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused the Tallow Creek to come out of it's banks and wash out a gravel road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm developed with the aid of afternoon heating in DeSoto Parish.  This thunderstorm developed in a very unstable airmass and produced strong and damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and large limbs were down in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system across central and northeast Texas produced flooding rainfall in a continual wet pattern in the southern plains. This complex of thunderstorms developed during the late night and early morning hours of the 14th and these storms were sustained by a strong low level jet from the south.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: About six roads were closed in the western portion of the county from heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed with the aid of afternoon heating across portions of southwest Arkansas on the 19th of July.  These thunderstorms produced cloud to ground lightning...one of which did some damage in Columbia County Arkansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck an oil and saltwater tank about 2 miles north of the La. state line just off Hwy. 79.  Resultant fire spread and burned 8 tanks...three of which completely melted.  Multiple fire agencies on the Louisiana and Arkansas side of the fire needed to be called in to extinguish the fire.  No injuries or evacuations were reported.

The storms produced damaging wind gusts and large hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in Mechanicville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds over west and south central Upper Michigan on the afternoon and evening of the 7th.  A tornado also formed over Menominee County and uprooted numerous trees west of the town of Banat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail lasted a couple of minutes...accompanied by heavy rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Thunderstorms produced large hail and damaging winds over west and south central Upper Michigan on the afternoon and evening of the 7th.  A tornado also formed over Menominee County and uprooted numerous trees west of the town of Banat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions developed during the afternoon of August 20th over eastern Nebraska as a warm front set up from central into southeast Nebraska by early afternoon.  Temperatures were in the 90s with dew points in the 70s south of the boundary.  A strong upper level disturbance that moved across the state helped trigger thunderstorm development by mid afternoon as it brought a wind shift of drier air eastward to meet the unstable conditions.  Severe thunderstorms quickly developed and they congealed into several bow echo type configurations as they tracked across both the Lincoln and Omaha metro areas and then into southwest Iowa.  Moderate amounts of wind damage was reported with the activity along with scattered large hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail was accompanied by winds strong enough to break 2 inch tree limbs.

Thunderstorms formed across the Southeast Nebraska Panhandle during the late afternoon hours and moved into the Western Sandhills region during the early evening hours. Hail ranging from quarter to golf-ball size was reported along with wind gusts near 60 mph.
Isolated thunderstorms formed over Northwest Nebraska during the afternoon hours and produced hail up to the size of nickels over northwest Cherry County.

Thunderstorms formed across the Southeast Nebraska Panhandle during the late afternoon hours and moved into the Western Sandhills region during the early evening hours. Hail ranging from quarter to golf-ball size was reported along with wind gusts near 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A nearly stationary thunderstorm produced heavy rain which washed out some roads.  One area of road that was washed out was approximately 100 yards long, 10 feet deep and 15-20 feet wide in places.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spilled south across western Iowa after a snowstorm left 2 to 4 inches of snow over the area the previous day.  Lows dropped to 5 below to 15 below over the area and when combined with north winds around 10 mph...wind chill values fell to 20 below to 30 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spread south across fresh snow that covered western Iowa this morning.  The cold air was ushered in on north winds of 10 to 15 mph.  When combined with actual low temperatures that fell to 10 below to 15 below zero, wind chill values of 20 below to 30 below zero were observed.  These bitter cold conditions lasted from around 200 am until 900 am.

When combined with actual low temperatures that fell to around 10 below zero, wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed. A warm front extended across northeast Nebraska during the afternoon of August 21st.  Instability by afternoon was moderately high along the front with temperatures of 85 to 90 and dew points in the mid 70s.  When combined with a strong jet stream across the Dakotas, scattered thunderstorms developed by late afternoon, a few of which became severe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through the mid south on its way into Southwest Virginia and Eastern Tennessee.  A large bow developed on the line late in the evening as it approached the Cumberland Plateau. Damage was predominantly created by straight line winds. However, an EF1 Tornado also developed on the Cumberland Plateau in Claiborne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were reported down, a mobile home was destroyed, and a garage roof was blown off in the northwest portion of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive night wind chill values dropped to at least 20 below over parts of western Iowa.  Northwest winds around 10 mph combined with temperatures that fell to 5 below to 10 below to produce these dangerously cold wind chills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed over the county as low temperatures dropped to 5 below to 10 below zero combined with northwest winds around 10 mph. These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around 5 am until 9 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around 7 am until 9 am.  It was the second consecutive day that wind chill values got this cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm that developed on a weak warm front clipped far northwest Knox county.  Most of the thunderstorm activity this evening was west or northwest of the region.

Severe thunderstorms developed along and behind a cold front that moved across eastern Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 14th. Arctic air plunged into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa on north winds of 15 to 25 mph.  As temperatures fell to zero to 5 below during the early morning hours of January 30, 2007, wind chill readings fell to 20 below to 25 below over sections of northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North winds of 15 to 25 mph and temperatures that dropped a little below zero created wind chill readings that fell to around 20 below.|These cold wind chill values were observed across the area from around 3 am until 10 am before moderating slightly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through the mid south on its way into Southwest Virginia and Eastern Tennessee.  A large bow developed on the line late in the evening as it approached the Cumberland Plateau. Damage was predominantly created by straight line winds. However, an EF1 Tornado also developed on the Cumberland Plateau in Claiborne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down in Philadelphia and a storm spotter measured wind speed at 73 mph.

Showers and thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana and quickly became severe producing large hail and damaging thunderstorm gusts. These storms were slow movers and given a very moist atmosphere present at the time across the region...flooding rainfall resulted from the storms across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  A few of these storms developed into southwest Arkansas...producing wind damage as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed in town.  One tree fell on a home which broke a gas line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Texas during the mid/late afternoon hours of the 27th, producing a large swath of tree, power line, and structural damage. These storms developed well ahead of a cold front that extended from southern and eastern Oklahoma, into central Arkansas, but mainly along a differential moisture boundary that moved south across east Texas, extreme southern Arkansas, and north Louisiana. Strong surface instability, and gust fronts that developed from these storms, focused new shower and thunderstorm development, with several of these storms becoming severe. One longer lived severe thunderstorm developed over eastern Upshur County, then merged with another southward moving band of strong thunderstorms, producing widespread wind damage across eastern Upshur, much of Gregg, and northern Rusk County. The cities of Longview and Kilgore were hit hardest, with numerous trees blown down/uprooted, power lines downed, and trees falling onto homes, with at least one known injury reported. A 53-yr old man was killed on the north side of Longview when lightning struck a tree he was standing near in wake of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple reports of downed trees near the community of Melrose.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low remained over the area triggering several rounds of showers and thunderstorms.  A very moist environment encouraged flash flooding on top of already saturated grounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low remained over the area triggering several rounds of showers and thunderstorms.  A very moist environment encouraged flash flooding on top of already saturated grounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were closed due to high water.  Significant flooding occurred with high water rescues required.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong line of thunderstorms moved into north Texas during the early morning hours, causing wind damage in several counties.  Storms redeveloped later in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High winds caused a large tree to fall in the city park.  Several other trees lost branches.  The tree was likely easily pushed over in the saturated grounds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system shifted slightly southward into central and south central Texas on the 4th of July.  This system continued to pump moisture northward into northeast Texas during the day which in turn...resulted in the development of showers and thunderstorms.  Many of these storms produced copious amounts of rainfall and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several secondary roads closed throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system developed across portions of central Oklahoma and north Texas during the overnight hours and early morning hours of July 5th.  This system moved into northeast Texas after sunrise and produced flood producing rainfall in a few counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding was reported in the areas surrounding Jacksonville, Texas.  Local law enforcement closed some city streets.  One vehicle was seen floating down a flooded roadway.  Stretches of Hwy 69 and 79 near town were flooded as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to flash flooding including county roads 2301...474...496 and 472.  A large sinkhole sits on county road 2301 after a culvert gave way.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms continued to produce flood producing rainfall across portions of northeast Texas as well as northwest Louisiana on July 6th.  Moisture continued to feed northward from the Gulf of Mexico which fueled these thunderstorms once they developed.  The region continued to be in a favorable area for thunderstorm development as an upper level area of low pressure remained anchored across central and north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Additional roads being closed as runoff accumulates on roadways across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave came down out of the northwest and produced low top convection.  Cold temps aloft caused hail to develop in several of the storms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front with strong dynamics and windshear pushed into the area late Saturday and early Sunday.  Hail and microbursts accompanied the first wave of storms while the second wave of storms produced a half dozen tornadoes.  The largest was an EF3 that killed on person and injured 3 others.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway dept reported several trees down on US 301 and I-26.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After one of the warmest March's on record, an unprecedented spell of cold weather hovered over the region between April 4th and April 10th. Low temperatures dropped into the upper teens and twenties. Trees and flowers which had budded or bloomed were extensively damaged. In addition...crop damage was extensive as well with many areas needing to be replanted. Most vineyards and fruit orchards had from 70 to 95 percent losses.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were downed near the 500 block of Fannin Street. Trees were also down on Broadway Avenue.

A broad area of low pressure which extended from the Dakotas south into the southern Rockies brought a period of snow to a portion of northeast Montana during the evening hours of the 28th into the early morning hours of the 29th.  The bulk of the snow fell from eastern Valley County and points east to the North Dakota border.  Snowfall amounts were generally in the 2 to 4 inch range.  A few isolated spots across the Big Sheep Mountains in Dawson and southern McCone Counties had up to 6 inches of snow.

These storms developed well ahead of a cold front that extended from southern and eastern Oklahoma, into central Arkansas, but mainly along a differential moisture boundary that moved south across east Texas, extreme southern Arkansas, and north Louisiana. Strong surface instability, and gust fronts that developed from these storms, focused new shower and thunderstorm development, with several of these storms becoming severe. The cities of Longview and Kilgore were hit hardest, with numerous trees blown down/uprooted, power lines downed, and trees falling onto homes, with at least one known injury reported. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions developed during the afternoon of August 20th over eastern Nebraska as a warm front set up from central into southeast Nebraska by early afternoon.  Temperatures were in the 90s with dew points in the 70s south of the boundary.  A strong upper level disturbance that moved across the state helped trigger thunderstorm development by mid afternoon as it brought a wind shift of drier air eastward to meet the unstable conditions.  Severe thunderstorms quickly developed and they congealed into several bow echo type configurations as they tracked across both the Lincoln and Omaha metro areas and then into southwest Iowa.  Moderate amounts of wind damage was reported with the activity along with scattered large hail reports.

A surface low rapidly deepened over NC during the early morning hours of April 15, 2007, as the parent upper level trough phased with the surface feature. A squall line of severe storms preceding a cold front moved through northeast Florida during the early morning hours of April 15th and produced multiple supercells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees were damaged about 3 miles west of Jacksonville Beach by thunderstorm wind gusts. One limb was about 12 feet long.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low rapidly deepened over NC during the early morning hours of April 15, 2007, as the parent upper level trough phased with the surface feature. A squall line of severe storms preceding a cold front moved through northeast Florida during the early morning hours of April 15th and produced multiple supercells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered trees and isolated power lines were blown down in northeast Baker county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spilled south across western Iowa after a snowstorm left 2 to 4 inches of snow over the area the previous day.  Lows dropped to 5 below to 15 below over the area and when combined with north winds around 10 mph...wind chill values fell to 20 below to 30 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spread south across fresh snow that covered western Iowa this morning.  The cold air was ushered in on north winds of 10 to 15 mph.  When combined with actual low temperatures that fell to 5 below to 10 below zero, wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed.  These bitter cold conditions lasted from around 200 am until 1100 am.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive night wind chill values fell to at least 20 below zero over most of northeast Nebraska.  Low temperatures fell to around 10 below zero and when combined with northwest winds around 10 mph...wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed over the county as low temperatures dropped to around 10 below zero combined with northwest winds around 10 mph.  These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around midnight through 1000 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and humid air aloft combined with a stationary front over southern Nebraska and caused scattered thunderstorms to develop over northeast Nebraska during the predawn hours of August 22nd.  A few of these storms turned severe over northeast Nebraska and extreme western Iowa a little after sunrise.

Warm and humid air aloft combined with a stationary front over southern Nebraska and caused scattered thunderstorms to develop over northeast Nebraska during the predawn hours of August 22nd.  A few of these storms turned severe over northeast Nebraska and extreme western Iowa a little after sunrise.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was accompanied by 50 mph winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through the mid south on its way into Southwest Virginia and Eastern Tennessee.  A large bow developed on the line late in the evening as it approached the Cumberland Plateau. Damage was predominantly created by straight line winds. However, an EF1 Tornado also developed on the Cumberland Plateau in Claiborne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and large limbs were reported down in the western part of Johnson City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana and quickly became severe producing large hail and damaging thunderstorm gusts. These storms were slow movers and given a very moist atmosphere present at the time across the region...flooding rainfall resulted from the storms across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  A few of these storms developed into southwest Arkansas...producing wind damage as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water across Linwood Road and the Inner Loop.  One car was submerged by water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front crossed the area during the late evening hours and produced severe weather.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Texas during the mid/late afternoon hours of the 27th, producing a large swath of tree, power line, and structural damage. These storms developed well ahead of a cold front that extended from southern and eastern Oklahoma, into central Arkansas, but mainly along a differential moisture boundary that moved south across east Texas, extreme southern Arkansas, and north Louisiana. Strong surface instability, and gust fronts that developed from these storms, focused new shower and thunderstorm development, with several of these storms becoming severe. One longer lived severe thunderstorm developed over eastern Upshur County, then merged with another southward moving band of strong thunderstorms, producing widespread wind damage across eastern Upshur, much of Gregg, and northern Rusk County. The cities of Longview and Kilgore were hit hardest, with numerous trees blown down/uprooted, power lines downed, and trees falling onto homes, with at least one known injury reported. A 53-yr old man was killed on the north side of Longview when lightning struck a tree he was standing near in wake of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust estimated about 1.5 miles east of the Cason community from a postal service employee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On 4/12, in the early morning hours, a line of severe thunderstorms produced some hail up to nickel size and some minor wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Convenience store reported penny size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On 4/12, in the early morning hours, a line of severe thunderstorms produced some hail up to nickel size and some minor wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tricounty Electric reported powerlines and large limbs down causing power outages just west of St. Matthews.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On 4/12, in the early morning hours, a line of severe thunderstorms produced some hail up to nickel size and some minor wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm survey found several trees down just north of Woodford on hwy 321.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front with strong dynamics and windshear pushed into the area late Saturday and early Sunday.  Hail and microbursts accompanied the first wave of storms while the second wave of storms produced a half dozen tornadoes.  The largest was an EF3 that killed on person and injured 3 others.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff reported trees down and roof blown off chicken house on hwy 178.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level storm system and strong cold front produced a widespread severe weather outbreak in northeastern Montana.  The majority of the events were high wind, a few reports of large hail, and two tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind was accompanied by pea sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous upper level storm system and strong cold front produced a widespread severe weather outbreak in northeastern Montana.  The majority of the events were high wind, a few reports of large hail, and two tornadoes.

Cold and dry high pressure built across the region behind a strong cold front. Strong cold air advection through the day and radiational cooling under clear skies and calm winds that night allowed several locations across the northwest Florida peninsula to fall below freezing for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum temperatures were generally in the upper 20s across the county, with the Brooksville ASOS reporting 28 degrees and the FAWN station reaching 29. The average duration of below freezing temperatures was 4 hours, with up to 8 hours in isolated locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold and dry high pressure built across the region behind a strong cold front. Strong cold air advection through the day and radiational cooling under clear skies and calm winds that night allowed several locations across the northwest Florida peninsula to fall below freezing for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum temperatures were generally around 30 across the county, with the RAWS station 12 miles southwest of Chiefland reporting 27 degrees and the FAWN station in Bronson reaching 32. The lowest temperature recorded was 26 degrees at the cooperative station 6 miles southeast of Chiefland. The average duration of below freezing temperatures was 5 hours, with up to 8 hours in isolated locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms continued to produce flood producing rainfall across portions of northeast Texas as well as northwest Louisiana on July 6th.  Moisture continued to feed northward from the Gulf of Mexico which fueled these thunderstorms once they developed.  The region continued to be in a favorable area for thunderstorm development as an upper level area of low pressure remained anchored across central and north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water covering the roadway of county road 213.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system interacted with a moist and unstable airmass over north Texas, resulting in large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A covered parking awning was lifted off its pillars and large limbs were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system interacted with a moist and unstable airmass over north Texas, resulting in large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near Knollwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system interacted with a moist and unstable airmass over north Texas, resulting in large hail, damaging winds, and flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After one of the warmest March's on record, an unprecedented spell of cold weather hovered over the region between April 4th and April 10th. Low temperatures dropped into the upper teens and twenties. Trees and flowers which had budded or bloomed were extensively damaged. In addition...crop damage was extensive as well with many areas needing to be replanted. Most vineyards and fruit orchards had from 70 to 95 percent losses.

The upper level trough of low pressure which continued to plague northeast Texas remained anchored across north Texas into southwest Arkansas and northwest Louisiana.  This system continued to advect deep tropical moisture from the Gulf of Mexico northward into the region.  The result was continued flooding rainfall across northeast Texas on the 8th of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets and roads flooded around town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flooding rainfall continued to spread across the region on July 9th as the upper trough of low pressure remained parked across our region. Plentiful moisture combined with daytime heating allowed for scattered to numerous showers and thunderstorms across southeast Oklahoma, southwest Arkansas, northwest Louisiana and northeast Texas resulting in flood producing rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of flooding at Beavers Bend State Park.  Other reports of water over the roadways in other portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broad area of low pressure which extended from the Dakotas south into the southern Rockies brought a period of snow to a portion of northeast Montana during the evening hours of the 28th into the early morning hours of the 29th.  The bulk of the snow fell from eastern Valley County and points east to the North Dakota border.  Snowfall amounts were generally in the 2 to 4 inch range.  A few isolated spots across the Big Sheep Mountains in Dawson and southern McCone Counties had up to 6 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front crossed the area and produced widespread severe weather across northeast Montana.  This was the biggest outbreak of severe weather during the month of May during at least the last 5 years.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golfball sized hail was followed by nickel sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow, producing heavy accumulations, was accompanied by winds gusting over 40 mph. The snow began early on March 1st after a brief respite from the previous snowfall, with winds increasing as the day went on. Blizzard conditions with widespread near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow resulted. Roads were blocked by drifting and travel was made impossible or extremely difficult. Interstate 90 was closed during the storm. Numerous businesses and schools were forced to close, and school athletic events and other activities were cancelled. Of those who did attempt to travel during the storm, several vehicles were stranded and others slid off roads. There were several power outages. The weight of the heavy snow and the winds caused several machine shed roofs to collapse in the Tyler to Marshall area, with some machinery damage resulting. The blizzard followed another significant snow 1 to 2 days before. The snow decreased on the night of March 2nd, with blizzard conditions abating by early morning on March 3rd. New snow accumulations ranged from 8 to 16 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: New snowfall of 12 to 15 inches beginning early morning on March 1st and continuing into the night of March 2nd was accompanied by sustained winds of over 30 mph at times with gusts over 40 mph. The combination of new snow, wind, and an already existing fresh snow cover resulted in a blizzard with widespread near zero visibilities. Drifting snow with the storm helped make travel impossible to extremely difficult. As a result, some who did attempt to travel became stuck or slid off roads. Schools and school activities were cancelled and numerous businesses closed. A few power outages were reported as the heavy snow and strong winds brought down power lines. The blizzard conditions abated early on the morning of March 3rd.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced large hail in southeast South Dakota, mainly near the Missouri River, during the late afternoon and early evening of August 21st. Very large hail fell in the Dante area in Charles Mix County, including a state record size hailstone certified as 6 and 7/8 inches in diameter.

Thunderstorms produced large hail in southeast South Dakota, mainly near the Missouri River, during the late afternoon and early evening of August 21st. Very large hail fell in the Dante area in Charles Mix County, including a state record size hailstone certified as 6 and 7/8 inches in diameter.

Thunderstorms produced large hail in southeast South Dakota, mainly near the Missouri River, during the late afternoon and early evening of August 21st. Very large hail fell in the Dante area in Charles Mix County, including a state record size hailstone certified as 6 and 7/8 inches in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large hail dented cars and cracked windshields. The amount of damage was not known.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface low rapidly deepened over NC during the early morning hours of April 15, 2007, as the parent upper level trough phased with the surface feature. A squall line of severe storms preceding a cold front moved through northeast Florida during the early morning hours of April 15th and produced multiple supercells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down by thunderstorm wind gusts along a rural road off of U.S. Highway 17, about 3 miles south of Bostwick.

A squall line of severe storms preceding a cold front moved through northeast Florida during the early morning hours of April 15th and produced multiple supercells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were blown down along State Road 100 in Bardin, about 3 miles west of Palatka.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure developed near the central Gulf coast states and tracked northeast along a nearly stationary front across south Georgia during the late afternoon of December 30th.  Pre-frontal storms developed across south Georgia where surface based lifted indices were near -2 to -3. Storms had persistent mesocyclone rotations and several storms developed bow echo signatures with outbound velocities around 40 to 50 knots along the leading edge of the bow around 3-4 kft above ground level prior to warning issuance.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The county dispatch reported several trees were blown down along Quincey Batten Loop near State Road 206. The cost of tree removal was estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions developed during the afternoon of August 20th over eastern Nebraska as a warm front set up from central into southeast Nebraska by early afternoon.  Temperatures were in the 90s with dew points in the 70s south of the boundary.  A strong upper level disturbance that moved across the state helped trigger thunderstorm development by mid afternoon as it brought a wind shift of drier air eastward to meet the unstable conditions.  Severe thunderstorms quickly developed and they congealed into several bow echo type configurations as they tracked across both the Lincoln and Omaha metro areas and then into southwest Iowa.  Moderate amounts of wind damage was reported with the activity along with scattered large hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter measured a thunderstorm wind gust of 68 mph which caused some tree damage in the area.

A large bow developed on the line late in the evening as it approached the Cumberland Plateau. Damage was predominantly created by straight line winds. However, an EF1 Tornado also developed on the Cumberland Plateau in Claiborne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were reported down and a bean shed was damaged near Deerlodge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive night wind chill values fell to at least 20 below zero over most of northeast Nebraska.  Low temperatures fell to around 10 below zero and when combined with northwest winds around 10 mph...wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed over the county as low temperatures dropped to around 10 below zero combined with northwest winds around 10 mph. These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around 6 am until 9 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive night wind chill values fell to at least 20 below zero over most of northeast Nebraska.  Low temperatures fell to around 10 below zero and when combined with northwest winds around 10 mph...wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed over the county as low temperatures dropped to around 10 below zero combined with northwest winds around 10 mph. These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around 6 am until 9 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm and humid air aloft combined with a stationary front over southern Nebraska and caused scattered thunderstorms to develop over northeast Nebraska during the predawn hours of August 22nd.  A few of these storms turned severe over northeast Nebraska and extreme western Iowa a little after sunrise.

For the second day in a row early morning thunderstorms dropped heavy rain over sections of northeast Nebraska.  The heavy rain brought 2 day totals, August 22nd and 23rd, to over 4 inches in places, including Norfolk where 4.34 inches of rain fell.  The thunderstorms developed north of a stationary front that had remained over sections of eastern Nebraska that morning and for several days prior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain pushed most small streams out of their banks flooding fields and a few county roads in the Monterey area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system moved out of the southwestern U.S. and dropped heavy snow over a large part of eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Winds during the event were relatively light, which limited the blowing and drifting. The snow began mid to late Saturday afternoon, 1/20/07, picked up in intensity from late afternoon into early evening and then began ending south to north Sunday morning between 800 am and 1000 am. Heavier snow amounts from this storm across eastern Nebraska included...9 inches in Prague, 8 inches in Papillion, Boystown and Fairbury, 7 inches at Fremont, Gretna, Nebraska City, Raymond, Hickman, Wayne and Loretto. Across southwest Iowa heavier amounts included...6 inches in Sidney, Council Bluffs, Little Sioux, and Clarinda and between 5 and 6 at Onawa, Castana and Shenandoah.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 6 inches was measured by the co-op observer near Little Sioux.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along and behind a cold front that moved across eastern Nebraska during the late afternoon and evening hours of May 14th. The storms also produced rainfall of 2 to 3 inches over parts of the region which caused flooding along the Little Blue River the next day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 2 to 3 inches fell over parts of the Little Blue River basin on May 14th causing the river to flood on the 15th.  A little over 2 1/2 inches was reported 7 miles northwest of Fairbury.  The Little Blue River at Fairbury climbed to around 16 feet at 215 pm cdt on May 15th, flood stage is 15 feet.  The river was above flood stage from around 9 am until 730 pm that day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. The severe reports generally consisted of large hail.
Severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. The severe reports generally consisted of large hail.
Severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. The severe reports generally consisted of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to 1 inch in diameter fell for several minutes in the Red Oak area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front over southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa. The severe reports generally consisted of large hail.

For the second time in May heavy rain fell across southwest Iowa with amounts of 2 to 4 inches common.  The rain developed along and northwest of a slow moving cold front that touched off a few severe thunderstorms the evening of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 2 to 4 inches fell across much of the lower Nodaway River basin from late on May 23rd until early on the 24th.  Clarinda reported 2.6 inches for the 24 hour total ending Thursday morning the 24th.  The heavy rain caused the Nodaway River to flood.  The river at Clarinda reached 23.8 feet a little after midnight CDT May 25th, flood stage is 19 feet.  The Nodaway River was above flood stage at Clarinda from around 8 am on May 24th until 1030 am on the 25th.|The high water closed a few county roads...especially around Braddyville and Shambaugh.  Some farmland along the river was also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Texas during the mid/late afternoon hours of the 27th, producing a large swath of tree, power line, and structural damage. These storms developed well ahead of a cold front that extended from southern and eastern Oklahoma, into central Arkansas, but mainly along a differential moisture boundary that moved south across east Texas, extreme southern Arkansas, and north Louisiana. Strong surface instability, and gust fronts that developed from these storms, focused new shower and thunderstorm development, with several of these storms becoming severe. One longer lived severe thunderstorm developed over eastern Upshur County, then merged with another southward moving band of strong thunderstorms, producing widespread wind damage across eastern Upshur, much of Gregg, and northern Rusk County. The cities of Longview and Kilgore were hit hardest, with numerous trees blown down/uprooted, power lines downed, and trees falling onto homes, with at least one known injury reported. A 53-yr old man was killed on the north side of Longview when lightning struck a tree he was standing near in wake of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees blown down in the Cookville community east of Mount Pleasant.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low remained over the area triggering several rounds of showers and thunderstorms.  A very moist environment encouraged flash flooding on top of already saturated grounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were closed due to flooding and voluntary evacuations occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranged from quarter size to two inches.  Southwest side of home received window and vinyl siding damage.  Double paned windows shattered on living room floor.  Trees on property shredded from hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front crossed the area and produced severe thunderstorms.

A strong sea-breeze boundary moved quickly northward out of southeast Texas and southwest Louisiana during the afternoon hours of the 26th.  A strong line of thunderstorms developed along the leading edge of the boundary causing sporadic strong winds that downed a few trees and power lines across portions of northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  Cloud to ground lightning was very intense as well and lightning resulted in scattered power outages in southwest Arkansas and northeast Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree fell on Mound Street at Hughes.  The tree knocked over power lines as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a transformer resulting in power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front with strong dynamics and windshear pushed into the area late Saturday and early Sunday.  Hail and microbursts accompanied the first wave of storms while the second wave of storms produced a half dozen tornadoes.  The largest was an EF3 that killed on person and injured 3 others.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sheriff reported trees down Holy Trinity Church road and Parr road, which is near Broad River Road.

Thunderstorms with heavy rains produced flash flooding on the evening of February 28th, which continued into the early morning hours of March 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms continued to produce flood producing rainfall across portions of northeast Texas as well as northwest Louisiana on July 6th.  Moisture continued to feed northward from the Gulf of Mexico which fueled these thunderstorms once they developed.  The region continued to be in a favorable area for thunderstorm development as an upper level area of low pressure remained anchored across central and north Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous county roads flooded and had to be closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After one of the warmest March's on record, an unprecedented spell of cold weather hovered over the region between April 4th and April 10th. Low temperatures dropped into the upper teens and twenties. Trees and flowers which had budded or bloomed were extensively damaged. In addition...crop damage was extensive as well with many areas needing to be replanted. Most vineyards and fruit orchards had from 70 to 95 percent losses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level storm system moved eastward out of north Texas during the morning of June 3rd and intensified as it moved into northeast Texas.  This system was embedded in northwesterly winds aloft which are often prolific wind producers if these systems can sustain themselves.  The storm system encountered a very unstable airmass across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana.  The result was widespread wind damage across the southern half of northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana through the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portion of a tin roof was ripped off a storage building in the Lake End community.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the wake of a strong storm system that pushed through the region on June 3rd...a very unstable airmass developed across the region during the afternoon hours of June 4th.  A weakening storm system across north central Texas moved eastward and resulted in the development of severe thunderstorms across portions of northeast Texas...southwest Arkansas and northwest Louisiana.  The storms produced damaging wind gusts and large hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system over the west combined with ample moisture over north Texas.  Storms trained over the same areas, creating flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: CR 425 was underwater and had to be barricaded.  In addition, a large section of CR 2232 washed away, leaving residents stranded without another road to use.  The flooding broke a large pipe under the road and left a hole about eight feet wide and twelve feet across.  The school bus could not pick up children, the mail could not be delivered, and the trash could not be picked up.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalled across north Texas...providing focus for afternoon thunderstorms.  There were several reports of hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system over the west combined with ample moisture over north Texas.  Storms trained over the same areas, creating flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent heavy rainfall over the span of a few days caused several backyard mudslides on the edge of Lake Granbury.  At one residence, large trees and about a hundred stone steps fell victim to the mudslide, sliding onto a boat dock below.  Numerous other waterfront properties experienced some damage due to shifting saturated grounds.  One residence lost their hot tub when the ground it was on fell into the lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system over the west combined with ample moisture over north Texas.  Storms trained over the same areas, creating flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man and his pick-up truck were swept into Fall Creek after he tried to cross a flooded low-water crossing.  A high water rescue was required.  Nearby residents were unable to go home in the evening due to the fact that their road, along the same creek, was flooded by as much as twelve feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain combined with rapid snow melt, led to some minor river flooding April 14th through April 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lamine River at Otterville crested at 15.99 feet, or 0.99 feet above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain combined with rapid snow melt, led to some minor river flooding April 14th through April 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system across north Texas allowed for slow moving thunderstorms to develop across portions of northeast Texas during the morning and afternoon hours of June 16th.  These thunderstorms produced copious amounts of rain with widespread flooding noted across some counties of northeast Texas.  Rainfall totals of some three to five inches were reported from these thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported across US 80 with minor street flooding in the northern portion of the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A carnival worker died at the site of the Wilson County Fair.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 48-year-old worker, helping to set up the Wilson County Fair, died while working outdoors. He rested inside his vehicle, but he did not turn on the air conditioner inside his truck. According to Mr. David McMurray, affiliated with Tennessee OSHA, he sat inside his truck with the doors open. The worker was from New Jersey. He became nauseous and fatigued while working, so he decided to rest. Coworkers could not revive him when he was found unconscious around 4 PM CST Wednesday August 15. Temperatures at Nashville International Airport reached 104 degrees with the dew point temperature in the middle 50s. This was below the heat advisory criteria of 105.   |

Thunderstorms produced large hail in southeast South Dakota, mainly near the Missouri River, during the late afternoon and early evening of August 21st. Very large hail fell in the Dante area in Charles Mix County, including a state record size hailstone certified as 6 and 7/8 inches in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very large hail included a hailstone 6 7/8 inches in diameter verified by the warning and coordination Meteorologist. The large hail included numerous stones around softball size. Damage included holes in roofs, broken rafters, broken awnings, numerous broken windows and dented vehicles, damaged siding, divots in the ground up to 12 inches long and 3 inches deep, and damaged crops. The amount of property and crop damage was not known.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced large hail in southeast South Dakota, mainly near the Missouri River, during the late afternoon and early evening of August 21st. Very large hail fell in the Dante area in Charles Mix County, including a state record size hailstone certified as 6 and 7/8 inches in diameter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large hail cracked windows and dented vehicles. The amount of damage was not known.

A strong cold front pushed east across east central New York and western New England during the afternoon hours of Tuesday June 5th. The interaction of this strong front, combined with a warm, moist and unstable air mass in place, led to the development of strong to severe thunderstorms across eastern New York and western New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported in Anaquassacook.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three-inch diameter tree limbs felled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the second consecutive night wind chill values fell to at least 20 below zero over most of northeast Nebraska.  Low temperatures fell to around 10 below zero and when combined with northwest winds around 10 mph...wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values of 20 below to 25 below zero were observed over the county as low temperatures dropped to around 10 below zero combined with northwest winds around 10 mph. These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around 4 am until 9 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

These bitter cold wind chills lasted from around 5 am until 9 am.  It was the second consecutive night that wind chill values got this cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very unstable conditions developed during the afternoon of August 20th over eastern Nebraska as a warm front set up from central into southeast Nebraska by early afternoon.  Temperatures were in the 90s with dew points in the 70s south of the boundary.  A strong upper level disturbance that moved across the state helped trigger thunderstorm development by mid afternoon as it brought a wind shift of drier air eastward to meet the unstable conditions.  Severe thunderstorms quickly developed and they congealed into several bow echo type configurations as they tracked across both the Lincoln and Omaha metro areas and then into southwest Iowa.  Moderate amounts of wind damage was reported with the activity along with scattered large hail reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was first reported by emergency management and then verified by a NWS storm survey and later by video from a storm chaser.  The tornado caused sporadic tree and crop damage from 3 1/2 miles south of Richland, on the north bank of the Platte River where it first touched down, to around 4 miles east of Richland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system moved out of the southwestern U.S. and dropped heavy snow over a large part of eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa. Winds during the event were relatively light, which limited the blowing and drifting. The snow began mid to late Saturday afternoon, 1/20/07, picked up in intensity from late afternoon into early evening and then began ending south to north Sunday morning between 800 am and 1000 am. Heavier snow amounts from this storm across eastern Nebraska included...9 inches in Prague, 8 inches in Papillion, Boystown and Fairbury, 7 inches at Fremont, Gretna, Nebraska City, Raymond, Hickman, Wayne and Loretto. Across southwest Iowa heavier amounts included...6 inches in Sidney, Council Bluffs, Little Sioux, and Clarinda and between 5 and 6 at Onawa, Castana and Shenandoah.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5 to 6 inches was measured by the co-op observers in Onawa and Castana.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air plunged into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa on north winds of 15 to 25 mph.  As temperatures fell to zero to 5 below during the early morning hours of January 30, 2007, wind chill readings fell to 20 below to 25 below over sections of northeast Nebraska and west central Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North winds of 15 to 25 mph and temperatures that dropped a little below zero created wind chill readings that fell into the 20 below to 25 below zero range.  These cold wind chill values were observed across the area from around 2 am until 9 am before moderating slightly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through the mid south on its way into Southwest Virginia and Eastern Tennessee.  A large bow developed on the line late in the evening as it approached the Cumberland Plateau. Damage was predominantly created by straight line winds. However, an EF1 Tornado also developed on the Cumberland Plateau in Claiborne county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down and a wind gust was estimated at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper low pressure system over the Dakotas combined with a band of moisture and instability over eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa to produce several severe thunderstorms.  The storms mainly produced marginally severe size hail, but isolated wind damage was noted.

For the second day in a row early morning thunderstorms dropped heavy rain over sections of northeast Nebraska.  The heavy rain brought 2 day totals, August 22nd and 23rd, to over 4 inches in places, including Norfolk where 4.34 inches of rain fell.  The thunderstorms developed north of a stationary front that had remained over sections of eastern Nebraska that morning and for several days prior.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain over several days caused a few small creeks in northern Colfax county to flood farm fields and several county roads.  Most of the flooding was near Highway 91, although the highway itself was not flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several days of heavy rain caused the Elkhorn River near West Point to flood.  The river at West Point reached a 13 foot crest around 3 pm CDT on 8/23/07, flood stage is 12 feet.  The river at West Point was above flood stage from around 1045 am on the 23rd until 145 am on the 24th.  The flooding affected mainly agricultural lowlands.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front extended across extreme southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa during the afternoon of August 7th.  Conditions along and south of the boundary were very unstable with temperatures well into the 90s and dew point temperatures in the mid and upper 70s.  Scattered thunderstorms...a few severe with heavy rain...developed along and north of the boundary.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds estimated at 60 mph downed power lines and tree limbs in Clarinda.  Several Lightning strikes to transformers and the downed power lines caused a little over 2000 residents to lose power in town for several hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper low remained over the area triggering several rounds of showers and thunderstorms.  A very moist environment encouraged flash flooding on top of already saturated grounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Streets were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level trough axis remained anchored across Central Texas...resulting in good southerly flow of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico into northeast Texas.  Scattered afternoon and evening thunderstorms developed in Rusk County some of which produced strong and damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees wee downed near county road 424 and FM 313.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early morning thunderstorms developed across portions of southwest Arkansas with an unstable and moist airmass in place.  These thunderstorms developed along a residual outflow boundary left over from the previous days convection.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike hit a home in Garland city burning the home to the ground.  There were no residents home at the time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours across northeast Texas and northwest Louisiana and quickly became severe producing large hail and damaging thunderstorm gusts. These storms were slow movers and given a very moist atmosphere present at the time across the region...flooding rainfall resulted from the storms across northeast Texas.  A few of these storms developed into southwest Arkansas...producing wind damage as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed just north of town across the Wilson Cemetery Road.  Trees were also downed near Hwy. 29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed across portions of East Texas during the mid/late afternoon hours of the 27th, producing a large swath of tree, power line, and structural damage. These storms developed well ahead of a cold front that extended from southern and eastern Oklahoma, into central Arkansas, but mainly along a differential moisture boundary that moved south across east Texas, extreme southern Arkansas, and north Louisiana. Strong surface instability, and gust fronts that developed from these storms, focused new shower and thunderstorm development, with several of these storms becoming severe. One longer lived severe thunderstorm developed over eastern Upshur County, then merged with another southward moving band of strong thunderstorms, producing widespread wind damage across eastern Upshur, much of Gregg, and northern Rusk County. The cities of Longview and Kilgore were hit hardest, with numerous trees blown down/uprooted, power lines downed, and trees falling onto homes, with at least one known injury reported. A 53-yr old man was killed on the north side of Longview when lightning struck a tree he was standing near in wake of the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down on CR 2237 in the community of Bagwell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rains produced flash flooding on the evening of February 28th, which continued into the early morning hours of March 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water over 47th and Elmwood and 47th and Troost, leading to several road closures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with heavy rains produced flash flooding on the evening of February 28th, which continued into the early morning hours of March 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous locations along US HWY 71 between Blue Parkway and 150th Street impassable due to high water.

A cold front with strong dynamics and windshear pushed into the area late Saturday and early Sunday.  Hail and microbursts accompanied the first wave of storms while the second wave of storms produced a half dozen tornadoes.  The largest was an EF3 that killed on person and injured 3 others.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported several trees down at the Santee golf course.

Moisture continued to feed northward from the Gulf of Mexico which fueled these thunderstorms once they developed.  The region continued to be in a favorable area for thunderstorm development as an upper level area of low pressure remained anchored across central and north Texas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After one of the warmest March's on record, an unprecedented spell of cold weather hovered over the region between April 4th and April 10th. Low temperatures dropped into the upper teens and twenties. Trees and flowers which had budded or bloomed were extensively damaged. In addition...crop damage was extensive as well with many areas needing to be replanted. Most vineyards and fruit orchards had from 70 to 95 percent losses.

Extensive heavy rainfall fell across portions of northeast Texas during the morning and early afternoon hours of July 31st.  These thunderstorms were part of a larger complex of thunderstorms that plagued the region during the late night hours of the 30th.  Counties that were hit the hardest included Titus and Camp counties where several roads had to be closed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inches of rainfall has resulted in flash flooding throughout the county. Reports of high water rescues from motorists stranded in high water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Campers were stranded along Glover River requiring rescue.  No one was injured.

The interaction of this strong front, combined with a warm, moist and unstable air mass in place, led to the development of strong to severe thunderstorms across eastern New York and western New England.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny size hail was reported in Hillsdale.

Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a late-season cold front and swept across large parts of South Florida during the evening hours of May 6th. The thunderstorms produced large hail, damaging winds and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several motorists reported a tornado about 1 to 2 miles north of Alligator Alley - I-75 - between mile markers 48 and 51. No damage was reported.

CZ_NAME: DEERFIELD BEACH TO OCEAN REEF FL
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a strong pressure gradient between a weak low pressure area over the western Bahamas and strong high pressure over the Northeast United States, along with deep moisture and instability east of an upper level low west of Naples, led to the formation of fast moving showers and thunderstorms which produced locally strong winds across Southeast Florida. Severe thunderstorms were observed over Southeast Miami-Dade County, and strong non-thunderstorm winds caused beach erosion in Palm Beach County.||This is a continuation of the episode which began on September 30.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Miami Beach handar station on 10th Street recorded wind gusts in excess of 34 knots with passing thunderstorms, with a peak wind gust of 47 mph (41 knots) at 1250 AM EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms mainly brought very heavy rains to south-central Nebraska. A few storms did produce some small hail and strong winds. Tree damage was reported in Cambridge, Wilsonville and southeast of Alma. Nickel sized hail fell in Holbrook and Cambridge, both in Furnas County. Flooding from thunderstorm rain runoff was reported in Howard, Hamilton, Buffalo and Kearney Counties. Some areas picked up from three to five inches of rain.
