Lightning caused a wildfire near Felda on May 19th which lasted until June. On May 24th, the fire jumped the southern periphery and threatened 30 homes in Felda, although no homes were damaged.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused a wildfire near Felda on May 19th which lasted until June. On May 24th, the fire jumped the southern periphery and threatened 30 homes in Felda, although no homes were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning on May 3rd sparked a wildfire in the Picayune Strand State Forest about 12 miles east of Naples.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning on May 7th sparked a wildfire in the Picayune Strand State Forest about 12 miles east of Naples. On May 8th, the fire damaged 3 homes  in the Golden Gate Estates area and threatened 33 others. ||The fire consumed 18,029 acres and occurred during extreme drought conditions during the winter and spring of 2007.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dry spring across South Florida combined with a prolonged period of below normal rainfall going back to early 2006 produced severe to extreme drought conditions across most of South Florida.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Well-below normal winter and spring rainfall along with a prolonged period of dry weather going back to early 2006 caused for severe drought conditions to spread southward across South Florida. As of May 29th, all of South Florida north of a West Palm Beach to Naples line was under D3 (extreme) drought status, with areas south of that line in a D2 (severe) drought status, with the exception of Miami-Dade County which was not considered to be in a drought.||Rainfall had begun to fall a little more regularly by the end of the month across eastern sections, but remained sporadic all month across interior and western areas.||The level of Lake Okeechobee continued to lower, and reached a all-time record low of 8.94 feet by May 31st. Significant impacts continued for the general public as water usage restrictions continued across South Florida. Phase 3 restrictions (50 percent reduction in usage) were in effect while the rest of South Florida was under Phase 2 restrictions (30 percent reduction). Wells across most of South Florida were running at below 10 percent of normal, and underground reservoirs were also running below normal area-wide.||The extremely dry conditions along with scattered thunderstorms early in the month resulted in several wildfires breaking out across South Florida as a result of lighning. One wildfire burned in the Big Cypress National Preserve in Collier County for over a month from a lightning strike on May 4th, with over 60,000 acres burned. Another wildfire in the Picayune Strand State Forest started from lightning on May 7th, burning over 18,000 acres. On May 8th, the fire damaged 3 homes in the Golden Gate Estates area and threatened 33 others. Yet another lightning-sparked wildfire in Hendry County started on May 19th, consuming over 4,000 acres and threatening homes in Felda.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Precipitation began as snow during the early morning hours across the mountains and foothills of South Carolina. The snow became moderate to heavy at times by sunrise. As much as 3 inches of snow had accumulated by 6 am. Snow, heavy at times continued during the mid and late morning hours across the mountains and foothills, with heavy snowfall totals occurring in most locations. The snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain over the foothills. Total snowfall accumulations of 2 to 5 inches were reported across the area by the time the snow tapered off around noon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late in the season artic airmass moved over the Central Plains at the beginning of April. Overnight temperatures in the period dropped into the teens and 20s. The coldest nights were on the 7th and 8th. On the 7th, the coldest readings were 10 degrees at Greeley and 15 at Lexington. On the 8th, coldest readings were 11 degrees at Greeley and Superior, 12 at York, and 13 degrees at Grand Island, Aurora and Ord.   On April 6th, 1 to 3 inches of snow fell from Lexington and Beaver City to Superior.

Precipitation began as light snow during mid-morning across portions of the North Carolina piedmont. The snow began to mix with and eventually changed over to sleet and freezing rain by late morning. Up to 2 inches of snow, along with light accumulations of sleet and ice occurred before a transition to rain in the early afternoon. Slick roads resulted in quite a few traffic accidents, especially along the I-40 corridor.

A winter storm moving to the south of the region brought very strong winds to south-central Nebraska. Accompanying the winds was some snow, especially east of Grand Island. The mixture of snow and wind caused very poor visibilities for a few hours. The worst visibilities were reported along US Highway 81 between Hebron and Columbus. Visibilities in this corridor were near zero at times in open country. The highest wind gusts, 59 mph, were at Ord and Grand Island. A 58 mph wind gust was reported at Aurora and Hastings reported a sustained wind over 40 mph between 9 and 10 pm.  No major damage was caused by the winds.

An unseasonably strong cold front was moving rapidly southeast through the eastern states early on the 4th.  This was supported by a very deep polar low intensifying across southeast Canada.  Very warm, humid, and unstable conditions continued in advance of this winterlike cold front.  A squall line of thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of the 3rd from the Ohio Valley into the Tennessee Valley.  This squall line continued to race out in advance of the front, reaching far north Georgia around midnight EDT and continued further south into central Georgia as a broken squall line during the early morning hours of the 4th.  Considerable wind damage occurred in association with the squall line across some north Georgia counties.  Several dozen homes were damaged in Hall county, including one blown off its foundation.  Other significant wind damage was noted in Dade and several other north Georgia counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported penny-sized hail on the west side of Trenton.  The Dade County Emergency Management Director observed pea-sized hail near Rising Fawn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first snow of the season moved into southwest Kansas during Friday, November 23rd and exited early Saturday, November 24th.  An upper level storm system moved out of southeastern Colorado Thursday night and by Friday morning was helping to draw moisture north from Oklahoma into southwestern Kansas.  This resulted in widespread light snow.  In general, 1 to 3 inches fell across the CWA.  The largest snowfall amount reported was 3.5 inches at Coldwater in Comanche County.   One 15 to 20 mile-wide band of 3 inches of snowfall fell from near Hugoton to northwest of Johnson.  Another swath 15 to 30 miles wide of 3-inch plus snowfall fell from Hays south through eastern Rush County and continued in the Larned, Kinsley and St. John areas.  One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The first snow of the season moved into southwest Kansas during Friday, November 23rd and exited early Saturday, November 24th. One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.

An unusual July cold front supported by a strong upper trough in the mid-Atlantic brought scattered thunderstorms to north and central Georgia during the afternoon. One of these briefly became severe in Cherokee county in north central Georgia producing quarter-sized hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported quarter-sized hail in the area between Canton and southwest of Free Home near the Fulton county line, while the Cherokee County Emergency Management Director observed penny-sized hail on the east side of the county.  In addition, a couple of trees were down off Union Hill Road south of Free Home near the Fulton County line.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that thunderstorm wind gusts blew a roof and several tin walls off a storage shed at Belda Farms incorporated in far easterly Dooly county near the Pulaski county line.

CZ_NAME: SW PASS OF THE MS R TO ATCHAFALAYA R LA OUT 20NM
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong thunderstorms developed across the coastal waters in an unstable atmosphere.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A waterspout was observed in the marshes outside of Galliano.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong late July cold front and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable atmosphere to produce one of the most widespread outbreaks of severe weather seen across the Peachtree City forecast area since mid-April.  The was marked by a mesoscale convective complex which began early in the day across northeast Alabama and quickly spread southeast through west central and into central Georgia during the afternoon.  Numerous reports of large hail were received and wind damage was widespread in the path of the convective complex.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public observed penny to nickel-sized hail in Peachtree City.  Pea-sized hail was observed at the National Weather Service Forecast Office about two miles south of Peachtree City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong late July cold front and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable atmosphere to produce one of the most widespread outbreaks of severe weather seen across the Peachtree City forecast area since mid-April.  The was marked by a mesoscale convective complex which began early in the day across northeast Alabama and quickly spread southeast through west central and into central Georgia during the afternoon.  Numerous reports of large hail were received and wind damage was widespread in the path of the convective complex.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Troup County 911 Center reported that approximately 20 trees were down from Hogansville to LaGrange.  Several power lines were down throughout this area as well.  One tree was down on a home in Hogansville causing moderate damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong late July cold front and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable atmosphere to produce one of the most widespread outbreaks of severe weather seen across the Peachtree City forecast area since mid-April. Numerous reports of large hail were received and wind damage was widespread in the path of the convective complex.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Meriwether County 911 Center reported that several trees and power lines were down in the southeast part of the county, southwest of Woodbury in the vicinity of Renolds Road and Georgia Highway 85.  One tree was down blocking a road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong cold front was moving rapidly southeast through the eastern states early on the 4th. A squall line of thunderstorms developed during the afternoon of the 3rd from the Ohio Valley into the Tennessee Valley. Considerable wind damage occurred in association with the squall line across some north Georgia counties.  Several dozen homes were damaged in Hall county, including one blown off its foundation.  Other significant wind damage was noted in Dade and several other north Georgia counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Cherokee Tribune reported that strong straight-line winds caused considerable damage in the Clayton Estates Community off Lower Burris road in north central Cherokee county.  A chicken house was destroyed and another was damaged.  A county school bus was destroyed when a large tree fell on the vehicle crushing the bus parked in the driver's yard.  Several other large trees were down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms developed across upstate New York and northeast Pennsylvania ahead of a slow moving cold front that extended from southern Ontario to lower Michigan. The airmass ahead of this front was warm and unstable, and with the aid of an upper level disturbance, severe thunderstorms developed over the area. Some of the storms produced very large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down near route 6 and route 84. Other roads were closed due to trees blocking roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep southwesterly flow developed ahead of an approaching cold front. Showers and thunderstorms developed in this warm and unstable environment, and some of the storms reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires were blown down in Butler Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds behind a cold front associated with strong low pressure caused damage in Garrett county Maryland, and Preston and Tucker counties in West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported trees down south of Mc Henry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High winds behind a cold front associated with strong low pressure caused damage in Garrett county Maryland, and Preston and Tucker counties in West Virginia.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported trees down in the Oakland area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season cold front brought high winds to the south Oregon coast on this date.  A High Wind Warning was issued at 24/0350 PST, effective from 24/0350 to 24/1600 PST.  The warning was cancelled at 24/1139 PST, at which time the event was verifying.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured at Gold Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season cold front brought high winds to the south Oregon coast on this date.  A High Wind Warning was issued at 24/0350 PST, effective from 24/0350 to 24/1600 PST.  The warning was cancelled at 24/1139 PST, at which time the event was verifying.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Recorded at Port Orford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season cold front brought high winds to the south Oregon coast on this date.  A High Wind Warning was issued at 24/0350 PST, effective from 24/0350 to 24/1600 PST.  The warning was cancelled at 24/1139 PST, at which time the event was verifying.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Recorded at Port Orford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong late July cold front and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable atmosphere to produce one of the most widespread outbreaks of severe weather seen across the Peachtree City forecast area since mid-April.  The was marked by a mesoscale convective complex which began early in the day across northeast Alabama and quickly spread southeast through west central and into central Georgia during the afternoon.  Numerous reports of large hail were received and wind damage was widespread in the path of the convective complex.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Treutlen County 911 Center reported that several trees and power lines were down, scattered about the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong late July cold front and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable atmosphere to produce one of the most widespread outbreaks of severe weather seen across the Peachtree City forecast area since mid-April.  The was marked by a mesoscale convective complex which began early in the day across northeast Alabama and quickly spread southeast through west central and into central Georgia during the afternoon.  Numerous reports of large hail were received and wind damage was widespread in the path of the convective complex.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emanuel County 911 Center reported that one tree and three power lines were down in Adrian along the Johnson county line.  The public reported that four more trees were down on U.S. Highway 221 around Norristown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another record breaking snow event for west Texas and southeastern New Mexico as an upper level storm system and a cold front move across the region.  Six to eight inches of snow in the Van Horn area resulted in Interstate 10 being closed between Fort Hancock and Fort Stockton and Interstate 20 being closed between Pecos and Fort Hancock.  At least 200 tractor trailers were stranded in Van Horn and Pecos when those interstates closed.  Schools across west Texas and southeastern New Mexico closed for at least a day.  Locations across the region received anywhere from an inch to eleven inches of snow.

Locations across the region received anywhere from an inch to eleven inches of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inches of snow fell in Seminole.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: November was yet another dry month for the Central Tennessee Valley.  Rainfall totals were generally between 2 and 3 inches areawide, except in a thin strip from Russellville to Courtland to North Huntsville to north of Scottsboro, where rainfall totals of 3 to 5 inches were realized.  These totals were still below normal areawide, however, so there was little relief to the ongoing historic drought.||Drought conditions were little changed during the month of November.  The only change occurred in the Shoals region, west of an Athens to Moulton line, where about a one category improvement in the U.S. Drought Monitor occurred between the end of October and the end of November.
A combination of a strong upper level disturbance and a cold front produced showers and thunderstorms over Eastern Arkansas on November 21st, 2007.
A combination of a strong upper level disturbance and a cold front produced showers and thunderstorms over West Tennessee on November 21st, 2007.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds knocked down a few trees in Henderson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of a strong upper level disturbance and a cold front produced showers and thunderstorms over West Tennessee on November 21st, 2007.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds overturned an 18-wheeler on Highway 51 North near Halls. In addition, a roof was blown off a mobile home and damaged its support on Edith Nankipoo Road. Several trees were also knocked down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through West Tennessee during the afternoon hours of November 14, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms accompanied the front through the area. Some of the storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds knocked down several trees on Key Corner Road near Unionville. In addition, power poles and power lines were knocked down near the Dyersburg Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through Eastern Arkansas during the afternoon hours of November 14, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms accompanied the front through the area. Some of the storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong gradient winds ahead of a cold front knocked down trees, power lines, and traffic lights in West Memphis. In addition, parts of a roof of a structure located at Broadway Boulevard and Missouri Street were blown off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low was located across North-Central Texas with a cold pool in the mid and upper level across South Texas, contributing to very steep mid level lapse rates and elevated instability.  Isolated elevated storms formed during the morning hours of the 14th across Victoria and Goliad counties, becoming severe with large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickle sized hail fell for 10 minutes on the southeast side of Victoria, near Business 59 and Loop 463.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The July drought continued through the first two weeks of August, 2007, over parts of south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  The area was north of a line from Baraboo to Watertown to Mequon.  The corn, alfalfa, and soybean crops were affected, especially in the higher areas or well-drained or poor soils. It is unknown how much of a monetary loss the drought generated.  Thundestorm rains gradually reduced the effects of the drought by mid-month.  D1 (moderate) drought conditions were observed, which improved to D0 (abnormally dry) by the middle of August , 2007.

A line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved northeast through southern Wisconsin.  Short segments of the line managed to bow out and generate isolated downbursts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerful thunderstorm downburst winds gusting to an estimated 56 knots (65 mph) toppled several large trees.  Tree branch debris knocked down some power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the evening of the 17th, an area of surface low pressure was located just northeast of Jamestown, North Dakota, with a cold front extending south from the low. A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were blown down in a mobile home park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept through central Wyoming bringing deep, moist northerly upslope flow to favored locations.  Six to ten inches of snow fell from Lander to Sweetwater Station.  Amounts of 12 to 14 inches were observed along the east slopes of the Wind River Mountains.  Sustained north wind of 20 to 30 mph with occasional higher gusts made for dangerous traveling conditions across central Wyoming.

Amounts of 12 to 14 inches were observed along the east slopes of the Wind River Mountains.  Sustained north wind of 20 to 30 mph with occasional higher gusts made for dangerous traveling conditions across central Wyoming.

Amounts of 12 to 14 inches were observed along the east slopes of the Wind River Mountains.  Sustained north wind of 20 to 30 mph with occasional higher gusts made for dangerous traveling conditions across central Wyoming.
Strong westerly flow produced high wind over Chief Joseph Pass where sustained wind was measured between 50 and 70 mph along State Highway 296.

A tightening pressure gradient ahead of an approaching cold front produced high wind across much of Natrona County.  A peak gust of 68 mph was recorded in Casper.  An automated station in western Natrona County measured gusts of 71 and 73 mph.

Just after midnight on the 26th, a stationary front was located along a Hallock (MN) to Cooperstown (ND) to near Mobridge (SD) line. By 3 am CST, a weak surface low formed south of Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, and a cold front had moved to a Cavalier (ND) to Cooperstown (ND) to Ellendale (ND) line. By sunrise, the cold front had progressed east to a Warroad (MN) to Bagley (MN) to Fergus Falls (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed in the late evening of the 25th near the front south of Cooperstown, but around midnight CST, another thunderstorm complex developed over north central North Dakota. These storms took an east-northeast track, eventually crossing into northwest Minnesota several hours later.

These storms took an east-northeast track, eventually crossing into northwest Minnesota several hours later.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 3 inches of rain fell in 2 to 3 hours, which flooded fields and farm access roads. Water also overtopped several township roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low moved from southern California eastward across the desert southwest, with southerly flow tapping abundant subtropical moisture in advance of the system. Cold low level flow did not push southward into southern NM and far west TX as strongly as anticipated, so an areawide heavy snow and ice storm episode did not materialize. However, some northern locations did receive substantial amounts of snow, while the majority of the area experienced heavy rain. Significant ice was limited to northeastern Hudspeth County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts included 6 inches at Mimbres and 9 inches in White Signal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moving out of Mexico producing a bow echo in northwest Webb County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The bow echo that impacted northwest Webb county continued northeast into southern La Salle county, causing damage in the town of Encinal.  There was damage to the siding of a few trailer homes.  The sheet metal on a several structures was peeled back, and even taken off in some cases.  Several large 8-12 inch diameter tree limbs were snapped.  Highway signs were also blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moving out of Mexico producing a bow echo in northwest Webb County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported in the San Carlos subdivision, with water in some homes.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line raced west to east across South Texas during the morning hours of June 5th.  A bow echo was observed along a portion of the squall line.  The apex of the bow accelerated through La Salle county, through central portions of South Texas and into the Coastal Bend (San Patricio and Nueces Counties).

A squall line raced west to east across South Texas during the morning hours of June 5th.  A bow echo was observed along a portion of the squall line.  The apex of the bow accelerated through La Salle county, through central portions of South Texas and into the Coastal Bend (San Patricio and Nueces Counties).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large two foot diameter trees were uprooted and blown over in Mathis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms during the evening hours produced numerous tornadoes and large hail across the southern...central and eastern Texas panhandle. Heavy rains caused flash flooding in the eastern Texas panhandle during the late night and early morning hours. One man was killed by a tornado in the northeastern Texas panhandle and another person was injured.

Hurricane Humberto was the only hurricane to strike the U.S. coastline during the 2007 hurricane season.  The hurricane, which rapidly strenghted from a tropical storm off the upper Texas coast late on the 12th, moved inland near the Texas-Louisiana border early on the 13th.  The remnants of Hurricane Humberto then tracked across central Louisiana, central Mississippi, and into northern Alabama on the 14th.  The center of the remnant of the track moved across extreme northwest Georgia, Dade and Walker county, on the 14th.  With north Georgia being located within the favorable right quadrant of the track, much needed rainfall fell across north central and northwest parts of the state, mainly northwest of a Rome to Gainesville line.  Rainfall amounts of two to three inches were common within this area, with isolated five to six  inch rainfall amounts in parts of Whitfield and Murray counties.  Further south, rainfall amounts were generally one inch or less.  However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.

A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms formed in advance of a cold front over much of South Central Texas early on the morning of January 13.  The storms produce spotty heavy rainfall as they tracked slowly northward along IH-35.  One of the thunderstorms developed into a supercell and produced a brief tornado near San Marcos.  Additional strong storms later formed along the front and produced additional spotty heavy rain along the IH-35 corridor as the front moved southward, with some areas experiencing flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shoal Creek near Lamar Street crested at 14.76  feet at 0915cst on January 13, where 10 feet is flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Subtropical moisture over the Desert Southwest fueled thunderstorms which brought heavy rain and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed and/or damaged by flooding, including U.S. Highway 93 20 miles north of Wikieup, Stockton Hills Rd. in the Kingman area, and Antares Rd. and Diamond Bar Rd. north of Kingman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Summer heat and monsoon humidity claimed a life.
A late-season surge of monsoon moisture fueled thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime-size hail fell for 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late-season surge of monsoon moisture fueled thunderstorms over the Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: More than a foot of water running over the roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot desert temperatures claimed a life.
Hot desert temperatures claimed another life.
Monsoon moisture fueled late-season thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blowing dust caused a ten-car pileup on Interstate 40 near Yucca.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Monsoon moisture fueled late-season thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning set fire to a drug store.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot desert temperatures claimed a life.

After a dry month of May, the heat and dry weather in June caused drought conditions to develop and intensify into the D2 classification for a portion of the western lowland counties.  Rain fed crops were struggling to mature. Much needed rain did fall during the last week of the month.

A strong ridge built north of the region with an elongated fetch area set up from near Bermuda to north Florida. A trough and eventually a low pressure center developed to the south of the region over the Bahamas and south Florida with a strong gradient flow between the two from September 29th through October 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Mayport National Oceans Service tide gauge measured 6.58 ft above Mean Lower Low Water (MLLW) which was about 0.8 to 1 ft above the predicted tide. Minor coastal flooding begins around 6.4 ft MLLW.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge built north of the region with an elongated fetch area set up from near Bermuda to north Florida. A trough and eventually a low pressure center developed to the south of the region over the Bahamas and south Florida with a strong gradient flow between the two from September 29th through October 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Flagler County Emergency Management Agency reported 7 to 11 foot breakers along Flagler Beach. They also reported a wind gust to 43 miles an hour from the northeast at 1010 am EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge built north of the region with an elongated fetch area set up from near Bermuda to north Florida. A trough and eventually a low pressure center developed to the south of the region over the Bahamas and south Florida with a strong gradient flow between the two from September 29th through October 2nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jacksonville Beach Red Cross Rescue Patrol reported minor coastal flooding of the street and parking lot. The flooding was due to wave runup from the high surf and the high tides due to a northeaster and was located on a beach access ramp between Red Cross building and a restaurant.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface ridge over the Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic and Tropical Storm Noel over the Caribbean produced a strong northeast flow regime over our local area. Strong and persistent onshore flow produced bands of heavy rainfall, high and rough surf as well as caused tidal flooding along our coastal counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Flagler county EM reported the following rainfall totals since midnight of 2 to 5 inches across Flagler county. Some the highest amounts were 4.91 inches at the Flagler Emergency Operations Center in Bunnell and 5 inches in South Flagler Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Well in advance of a cold front, one thunderstorm complex tracked across eastern Kentucky into southwest Virginia, then affecting McDowell County, before continuing southeast in Virginia.  Later in the evening, and closer to the surface front, storms moved across northern West Virginia.

A strong surface ridge over the Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic and Tropical Storm Noel over the Caribbean produced a strong northeast flow regime over our local area. Strong and persistent onshore flow produced bands of heavy rainfall, high and rough surf as well as caused tidal flooding along our coastal counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Fernandina Beach NOS gauge reported 8.91 ft MLLW which was 1.41 ft above predicted tide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stacked high pressure over the Mid-Atlantic region and low pressure over the Bahamas persisted for several days and brought deep tropical Atlantic moisture over our area under light steering flow. Periods of heavy rainfall during early October produced areal flooding in some areas across the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 5 pm on 10/4, Emergency Management reported water covering roads about 4-5 inches deep about 6 miles northwest of Starke at the intersection of State Road 16 and Highway 225. Water was approaching some homes and power outage occurred. Around 510 pm, a one mile stretch of U.S. Highway 301 was closed in Starke due to flooding between State Road 16 and State Road 100. Water was up to 3 ft in some places. At 257 pm on 10/5, emergency management reported that State Road 100 was flooded but still passable near the Bradford-Clay county line. The county public works put caution signs near flooded areas. ||water is covering the road about 4 to 5 inches deep near  intersection of highway 16 and highway 225. water is near some houses. power outages were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stacked high pressure over the Mid-Atlantic region and low pressure over the Bahamas persisted for several days and brought deep tropical Atlantic moisture over our area under light steering flow. Periods of heavy rainfall during early October produced areal flooding in some areas across the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The media measured 3.95 inches of rain between 1000 am and 430 pm just south of the University of North Florida.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stacked high pressure over the Mid-Atlantic region and low pressure over the Bahamas persisted for several days and brought deep tropical Atlantic moisture over our area under light steering flow. Periods of heavy rainfall during early October produced areal flooding in some areas across the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The media measured 3.55 inches of rain from midnight through 8 pm on 10/6/07.  The 7 day rainfall total 17.95 inches at his location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions continued into November in far southwest Virginia, advancing to an extreme drought across western Tazewell, western Smyth, and southwest Grayson counties by the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions existed at the beginning of November and continued until the end of the month. In western sections of the county, the drought worsened to the extreme level by November 6th, and persisted until the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy tropical rainfall across eastern Jim Wells county and western Bee county resulted in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 2 and 4 inches of rain fell late on the 23rd and during the early morning hours of the 24th across rural, western Bee county.  Several Farm to Market roads were flooded and closed, including F.M. 796, F.M. 888 and F.M. 797.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall during the earl morning resulted in flooding in the city of Victoria.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 1 and 3 inches of rainfall fell during the early morning across central Victoria county.  City streets in Victoria flooded around Second Street and Liberty and Second Street and Williams.  At least 10 homes had up to 6 inches of water in them from the flooding.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced intense rainfall of 2 to 2.5 inches within a 90 minute period during the late afternoon hours of the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew a roof off of a carport and knocked down a power line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: November was yet another dry month for the Central Tennessee Valley. Rainfall totals were generally between 2 and 3 inches areawide. These totals were below normal areawide, however, so there was little relief to the ongoing historic drought.

November was yet another dry month for the Central Tennessee Valley. Rainfall totals were generally between 2 and 3 inches areawide. These totals were below normal areawide, however, so there was little relief to the ongoing historic drought.

November was yet another dry month for the Central Tennessee Valley.  Rainfall totals were generally between 2 and 3 inches areawide, except in a thin strip from Russellville to Courtland to North Huntsville to north of Scottsboro, where rainfall totals of 3 to 5 inches were realized.  These totals were still below normal areawide, however, so there was little relief to the ongoing historic drought.||Drought conditions were little changed during the month of November.  The only change occurred in the Shoals region, west of an Athens to Moulton line, where about a one category improvement in the U.S. Drought Monitor occurred between the end of October and the end of November.

An upper level disturbance moved through West Tennessee during the morning of November 13th, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms developed in association with the disturbance. Some storms produced damaging winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds produced damage to an awning at the Anderson Fruit Stand and to the nursery located across the road from the Anderson Fruit Stand. In addition, a trailer was blown over and demolished. The trailer was located nearby.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved through West Tennessee during the morning of November 13th, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms developed in association with the disturbance. Some storms produced damaging winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds blew down 5 power poles on Highway 64 near the Fayette  and Hardeman County border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through Eastern Arkansas during the afternoon hours of November 14, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms accompanied the front through the area. Some of the storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds blew down a few power lines in Jericho.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low stalled west of Baja for several days bringing northward ample subtropical moisture. On November 30th the upper low pushed east toward Arizona brining heavy rainfall and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured gust to 123mph was reported at Kitt Peak. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ample monsoonal moisture combined with daytime heating caused strong thunderstorms over Santa Cruz County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm over the city of Nogales caused hail one inch in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Short lines of severe thunderstorms moved east-northeast through south-central and southeast Wisconsin during the overnight hours.  Some cell movement exceeded 43 kts (50 mph) to the east.  Powerful downburst winds reached hurricane-force at 64 knots or higher (74 mph+), resulting in considerable tree and power-line damage.  Synoptically, a stationary front stretched from northern Iowa to northern Illinois.  Warm, moist, unstable air flowed north over the front in association with an upper-level short-wave trough, resulting in thunderstorm generation.

Short lines of severe thunderstorms moved east-northeast through south-central and southeast Wisconsin during the overnight hours.  Some cell movement exceeded 43 kts (50 mph) to the east.  Powerful downburst winds reached hurricane-force at 64 knots or higher (74 mph+), resulting in considerable tree and power-line damage.  Synoptically, a stationary front stretched from northern Iowa to northern Illinois.  Warm, moist, unstable air flowed north over the front in association with an upper-level short-wave trough, resulting in thunderstorm generation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerful thunderstorm wind gusts to 52 knots (60 mph) toppled several large trees and damaged several power-lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thundestorms with plenty of lightning rolled through south-central Wisconsin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a commerical peg farm near Sauk City, killing about 1900 pigs.  The exact location of the farm isn't known.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved northeast through southern Wisconsin.  Short segments of the line managed to bow out and generate isolated downbursts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerful thunderstorm downburst winds gusting to an estimated 56 knots (65 mph) toppled several large trees.  Tree branch debris knocked down some power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved northeast through southern Wisconsin.  Short segments of the line managed to bow out and generate isolated downbursts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerful thunderstorm downburst winds gusting to an estimated 56 knots (65 mph) toppled several large trees.  Tree branch debris knocked down some power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over northeast Iowa and northern Illinois combined with an unstable air mass to produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of June 21st. The stronger storms produced damaging winds and large hail. Heavy rain was also common with the storms, which caused some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down across 750 Ave N near 450 St E.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over northeast Iowa and northern Illinois combined with an unstable air mass to produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of June 21st. The stronger storms produced damaging winds and large hail. Heavy rain was also common with the storms, which caused some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree branches were blown down between Wayland and Alexandria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of showers and thunderstorm move across areas north of Highway 30 during the afternoon and evening hours of August 6th and the early morning hours of the 7th.  Heavy rains were widespread across these areas, with some isolated wind damage in Buchanan County.  Stephenson County Illinois was hardest hit with rainfall, where totals of three to seven inches fell, which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains of 3 to 7 inches fell during the early morning hours of August 7th in Jo Daviess County.  Flash flood waters washed out several county roads southeast of Stockton and east of the Plum River.  Delayed report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tightening pressure gradient ahead of an approaching cold front produced high wind across much of Natrona County.  A peak gust of 68 mph was recorded in Casper.  An automated station in western Natrona County measured gusts of 71 and 73 mph.

A Pacific storm system and associated cold front caused heavy snow and considerable wind across western Wyoming on Christmas Eve.  Snowfall of around six inches was reported in the Star Valley with slightly more than one foot in the nearby mountains.  As the storm moved east of the Continental Divide it brought favorable northerly upslope flow to the Lander Foothills.  A quick six to eight inches of snow was recorded by early Christmas morning in and near Lander.

Just after noon, a stationary front was located along a line from Rugby (ND) to Pembina (ND) to southwest Ontario, Canada. By late afternoon, the front had become a cold front and moved to a Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN) to Flag Island (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed across extreme northeast North Dakota and extreme northwest Minnesota. These storms moved northeast and weakened over southwest Ontario.

Just after noon, a stationary front was located along a line from Rugby (ND) to Pembina (ND) to southwest Ontario, Canada. By late afternoon, the front had become a cold front and moved to a Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN) to Flag Island (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed across extreme northeast North Dakota and extreme northwest Minnesota. These storms moved northeast and weakened over southwest Ontario.

Just after midnight on the 26th, a stationary front was located along a Hallock (MN) to Cooperstown (ND) to near Mobridge (SD) line. By 3 am CST, a weak surface low formed south of Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, and a cold front had moved to a Cavalier (ND) to Cooperstown (ND) to Ellendale (ND) line. By sunrise, the cold front had progressed east to a Warroad (MN) to Bagley (MN) to Fergus Falls (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed in the late evening of the 25th near the front south of Cooperstown, but around midnight CST, another thunderstorm complex developed over north central North Dakota. These storms took an east-northeast track, eventually crossing into northwest Minnesota several hours later.

Just after midnight on the 26th, a stationary front was located along a Hallock (MN) to Cooperstown (ND) to near Mobridge (SD) line. By 3 am CST, a weak surface low formed south of Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, and a cold front had moved to a Cavalier (ND) to Cooperstown (ND) to Ellendale (ND) line. By sunrise, the cold front had progressed east to a Warroad (MN) to Bagley (MN) to Fergus Falls (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed in the late evening of the 25th near the front south of Cooperstown, but around midnight CST, another thunderstorm complex developed over north central North Dakota. These storms took an east-northeast track, eventually crossing into northwest Minnesota several hours later.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large branches were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across northeast Mexico in the afternoon hours, and became severe with supercell characteristics in a highly unstable environment.  The severe storms crossed the Rio Grande River into Webb County and the Rio Grande Plains.  A few of the storms made it into the western Coastal Plains, but weakened as they encountered a more stable environment.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds from a severe thunderstorm resulted in damage across the west side of Beeville.  A 4 by 8 section of a one story apartment on West Fannin St. was blown off by the winds.  There was damage to large tree limbs in the area and a large hackberry tree was blown down, damaging three vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall trained southwest to northeast across the central sections of Goliad and Victoria counties.  A band of 3 to 6 inches of rain fell over a 3 hour period from southwest Goliad to northeast Victoria county, resulting in flash flooding.  3.22 of rain fell at the Victoria Regional Airport establishing a new daily rainfall record for this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding of a low water crossing along U.S. 59 was reported roughly 10 miles southwest of Goliad.  U.S. 59 was reduced to one lane.  Law enforcement reported one vehicle was swept off the road, but the driver was able to escape unharmed.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall trained southwest to northeast across the central sections of Goliad and Victoria counties.  A band of 3 to 6 inches of rain fell over a 3 hour period from southwest Goliad to northeast Victoria county, resulting in flash flooding.  3.22 of rain fell at the Victoria Regional Airport establishing a new daily rainfall record for this date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds broke several large tree limbs across the north side of Victoria.  A few fences were also blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line raced west to east across South Texas during the morning hours of June 5th.  A bow echo was observed along a portion of the squall line.  The apex of the bow accelerated through La Salle county, through central portions of South Texas and into the Coastal Bend (San Patricio and Nueces Counties).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several tall, large trees, some 3 feet in diameter, were uprooted and blown over in and around the Odem and Mathis areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line raced west to east across South Texas during the morning hours of June 5th.  A bow echo was observed along a portion of the squall line.  The apex of the bow accelerated through La Salle county, through central portions of South Texas and into the Coastal Bend (San Patricio and Nueces Counties).
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tall, large 2-3 foot diameter tree was snapped in half in Gregory Park by the thunderstorm wind gusts.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary set up in the early morning hours of the 25th from Dickinson (ND) to Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN). This boundary held in place for the next three hours, then finally sagged toward a Baudette (MN) to Grand Forks (ND) line around sunrise. Thunderstorms initially developed across southern Manitoba and northwest North Dakota, which brushed the international border area north of Devils Lake. Around sunrise, a better developed line of thunderstorms formed in northeast North Dakota and moved into northwest Minnesota, where they quickly weakened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain flooded fields and a county road near Hidden Island Coulee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary set up in the early morning hours of the 25th from Dickinson (ND) to Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN). This boundary held in place for the next three hours, then finally sagged toward a Baudette (MN) to Grand Forks (ND) line around sunrise. Thunderstorms initially developed across southern Manitoba and northwest North Dakota, which brushed the international border area north of Devils Lake. Around sunrise, a better developed line of thunderstorms formed in northeast North Dakota and moved into northwest Minnesota, where they quickly weakened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary set up in the early morning hours of the 25th from Dickinson (ND) to Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN). This boundary held in place for the next three hours, then finally sagged toward a Baudette (MN) to Grand Forks (ND) line around sunrise. Thunderstorms initially developed across southern Manitoba and northwest North Dakota, which brushed the international border area north of Devils Lake. Around sunrise, a better developed line of thunderstorms formed in northeast North Dakota and moved into northwest Minnesota, where they quickly weakened.

Hurricane Humberto was the only hurricane to strike the U.S. coastline during the 2007 hurricane season.  The hurricane, which rapidly strenghted from a tropical storm off the upper Texas coast late on the 12th, moved inland near the Texas-Louisiana border early on the 13th.  The remnants of Hurricane Humberto then tracked across central Louisiana, central Mississippi, and into northern Alabama on the 14th.  The center of the remnant of the track moved across extreme northwest Georgia, Dade and Walker county, on the 14th.  With north Georgia being located within the favorable right quadrant of the track, much needed rainfall fell across north central and northwest parts of the state, mainly northwest of a Rome to Gainesville line.  Rainfall amounts of two to three inches were common within this area, with isolated five to six  inch rainfall amounts in parts of Whitfield and Murray counties.  Further south, rainfall amounts were generally one inch or less.  However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Humberto was the only hurricane to strike the U.S. coastline during the 2007 hurricane season.  The hurricane, which rapidly strenghted from a tropical storm off the upper Texas coast late on the 12th, moved inland near the Texas-Louisiana border early on the 13th.  The remnants of Hurricane Humberto then tracked across central Louisiana, central Mississippi, and into northern Alabama on the 14th.  The center of the remnant of the track moved across extreme northwest Georgia, Dade and Walker county, on the 14th.  With north Georgia being located within the favorable right quadrant of the track, much needed rainfall fell across north central and northwest parts of the state, mainly northwest of a Rome to Gainesville line.  Rainfall amounts of two to three inches were common within this area, with isolated five to six  inch rainfall amounts in parts of Whitfield and Murray counties.  Further south, rainfall amounts were generally one inch or less.  However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front sagged south across the state during the previous night and became stationary east-west over far southern Iowa.  The airmass became very unstable during the afternoon as temperatures soared into the low to mid 90s.  Dew points pooled over southwest into west central Iowa and were in the upper 70s to low 80s across the area.  This lead to CAPE values in excess of 7000 J/kg and a lifted index of -12 C.  Needless to say, considerable moisture was available with precipitable water values in the 2 to 2.25 inch range.  Thunderstorms developed over Nebraska and moved into Iowa during the afternoon.  A strong bow echo developed and advanced east-southeast across the west central, then across the south west into the south central counties of the state.  Some of the storms produced hail, but the hail was below severe levels.  In spite of the available cape in the -10 to -30 C. layer of the atmosphere being in the 600 to 900 J/kg range, hail was suppressed once again by the high freezing levels.  Freezing levels were between 14,500 and 15,000 feet.  The LCL was a relatively low 750 to 1000 meters, however downdraft CAPE was very high, between 1200 and 1600 J/kg.  Winds dominated the event as the storms advanced rapidly eastward in a shear environment of 40 to 50 kts.  There were numerous reports of trees toppled and power line damage.  Wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH were common.  Some of the higher gusts came from the Adair area.  Mesonet sites reported wind gusts of 66 to 71 MPH in the area.

Severe thunderstorms during the evening hours produced numerous tornadoes and large hail across the southern...central and eastern Texas panhandle. Heavy rains caused flash flooding in the eastern Texas panhandle during the late night and early morning hours. One man was killed by a tornado in the northeastern Texas panhandle and another person was injured.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported on State Highway 70 in northern Roberts County about four miles south of the Roberts County and Ochiltree County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms during the evening hours produced numerous tornadoes and large hail across the southern...central and eastern Texas panhandle. Heavy rains caused flash flooding in the eastern Texas panhandle during the late night and early morning hours. One man was killed by a tornado in the northeastern Texas panhandle and another person was injured.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water reported to be in some homes as well as the Fire Department and Civic Center. Water at least one foot deep on city streets.

CZ_NAME: LAKE MEAD/LAKE MOHAVE NATIONAL RECREATION AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds ahead of an incoming low pressure system caused dangerous conditions on Lake Mead.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A windsurfer wiped out and drowned in strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought thunderstorms and heavy rain to the Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads and attractions were closed in Death Valley National Park due to flooding, mud and debris.  Time of damage occurrence unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought thunderstorms and heavy rain to the Mojave Desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Diamond Bar Rd. was closed and washes were flooded in Meadview.

CZ_NAME: EASTERN SIERRA SLOPES OF INYO COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Pacific storm system brought strong southwest winds to portions of the Mojave Desert and Southern Great Basin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occurred 5 miles WSW of Independence, CA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front near the Georgia/Tennessee line and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable air mass to produce widespread thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening.  Several of these became severe producing hail and damaging downburst winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reports that an apparent thunderstorm downburst or microburst resulted in six or more large trees down in a heavily wooded neighborhood in north Cobb county.  Streets included were Devonshire Drive, Buckingham Circle, and Sunset Circle.  One tree was down on a home, causing damage to the structure.  A couple of trees were down on power lines, and Devonshire Road was blocked from a downed tree.  Some of the trees were at least 100-years old.  In addition, a street sign was down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front near the Georgia/Tennessee line and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable air mass to produce widespread thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening.  Several of these became severe producing hail and damaging downburst winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rockdale Citizen of Conyers reported that lightning struck a home on Georgia Highway 20 entering the house via metallic water and gas lines.  A portion of the floor of the home was damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front near the Georgia/Tennessee line and northwest flow aloft combined with a moist and unstable air mass to produce widespread thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening.  Several of these became severe producing hail and damaging downburst winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Gainesville Times reported that lightning struck several trees on McEver Road, toppling them and causing them to catch on fire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface ridge over the Ohio Valley and mid-Atlantic and Tropical Storm Noel over the Caribbean produced a strong northeast flow regime over our local area. Strong and persistent onshore flow produced bands of heavy rainfall, high and rough surf as well as caused tidal flooding along our coastal counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee reported several inches of water covering the roads in downtown St. Augustine near Flagler College and St. George Street. About 3 inches of rainfall accumulated since midnight.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The large upper low over the northeastern U.S. continued and was actually sinking a little further south toward the mid-Atlantic.  As a result, scattered thunderstorms developed once again during the heat of the afternoon from northerly flow and cold air aloft.  A few became severe producing marginal severe hail and downburst winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public observed penny-sized hail on the north side of Peachtree City in the Kedron area.  One-quarter to one-half inch diameter hail was observed at the National Weather Service Forecast Office on the south side of Peachtree City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Yet another short wave in northwest flow brought thunderstorms to mainly the northwest part of the state.  All but one remained below severe limits, however.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported quarter-sized hail at a marina on Lake Allatoona.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: June 25th proved to be one of the more significant severe weather days during the month.  This was the result of a strong short wave in westerly flow aloft and a very unstable and moist atmosphere present over the area.  Damaging downburst winds, large hail, and most significantly a number of lightning incidents were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An employee of the Jackson Electric Membership Cooperative, which provides power to this local area, reported that six trees were down along Roy Parks Road east to northeast of Candler.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: June 25th proved to be one of the more significant severe weather days during the month.  This was the result of a strong short wave in westerly flow aloft and a very unstable and moist atmosphere present over the area.  Damaging downburst winds, large hail, and most significantly a number of lightning incidents were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Hall County 911 Center reported that lightning struck a building in the city causing minor damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Stacked high pressure over the Mid-Atlantic region and low pressure over the Bahamas persisted for several days and brought deep tropical Atlantic moisture over our area under light steering flow. Periods of heavy rainfall during early October produced areal flooding in some areas across the forecast area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jacksonville Beach Life Guards reported 4 rip currents rescues on 10/06. On 10/7, the guards reported that there were dangerous rips all day and surf was 3-4 ft.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary set up in the early morning hours of the 25th from Dickinson (ND) to Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN). This boundary held in place for the next three hours, then finally sagged toward a Baudette (MN) to Grand Forks (ND) line around sunrise. Thunderstorms initially developed across southern Manitoba and northwest North Dakota, which brushed the international border area north of Devils Lake. Around sunrise, a better developed line of thunderstorms formed in northeast North Dakota and moved into northwest Minnesota, where they quickly weakened.

Just after noon, a stationary front was located along a line from Rugby (ND) to Pembina (ND) to southwest Ontario, Canada. By late afternoon, the front had become a cold front and moved to a Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN) to Flag Island (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed across extreme northeast North Dakota and extreme northwest Minnesota. These storms moved northeast and weakened over southwest Ontario.

Just after noon, a stationary front was located along a line from Rugby (ND) to Pembina (ND) to southwest Ontario, Canada. By late afternoon, the front had become a cold front and moved to a Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN) to Flag Island (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed across extreme northeast North Dakota and extreme northwest Minnesota. These storms moved northeast and weakened over southwest Ontario.

Just after noon, a stationary front was located along a line from Rugby (ND) to Pembina (ND) to southwest Ontario, Canada. By late afternoon, the front had become a cold front and moved to a Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN) to Flag Island (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed across extreme northeast North Dakota and extreme northwest Minnesota. These storms moved northeast and weakened over southwest Ontario.

Major flooding was observed during July 2007 as record rainfall occurred over South Texas.  By the time the month ended, most river locations exceeded flood levels at least once during the 31 day period.  ||During the first part of July, a persistent, nearly stationary upper level low which brought catastrophic flooding to North Texas late in June moved south during the first few days in July, resulting in very heavy rainfall and widespread flooding over much of the area. Dozens of flash flood warnings were issued, and moderate to major flooding was observed over most rivers east of the Rio Grande. In fact, some of the river crests observed were comparable to those observed during July 2002 and September 2002, when record flooding was observed over the Nueces River basin. Six locations had crests which were within the top five highest crests ever recorded:||	Nueces River at Calallen (4th highest)|	Nueces River at Bluntzer (3rd highest)|	Aransas River at Skidmore (3rd highest)|	Garcitas Creek near Inez (3rd highest)|	Oso Creek near Corpus Christi (5th highest)|	Copano Creek near Refugio (3rd highest)||The reservoirs for the Corpus Christi water supply quickly filled, and required releases brought major flooding to the Nueces River south of Lake Corpus Christi.  In fact, Bluntzer and Calallen remained above flood stage through July (in part due to rainfall received later in the month). ||The Corpus Christi International Airport had the second highest monthly rainfall amount, totaling 18.13 inches (the highest was September 1967 with the remnants of Hurricane Beulah). The Victoria Regional Airport received 20.34 inches. Obviously, all of this excessive rainfall completely filled the reservoirs, with both Choke Canyon and Lake Corpus Christi continuing to release water through July 31.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Both the Nueces River at Calallen and the Nueces River at Bluntzer recorded major flooding in July.  Several homes were flooded forcing evacuations.  Disaster declarations were declared for both San Patricio and Nueces counties due to this river flooding.  Dollar estimates on the damage were not known at the time of this writing.  Flooding of the Nueces River in this area began on June 29th and continued through August 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An northwest flow of cold and unstable air aloft allowed scattered thunderstorms to develop and move southeast through southeastern Wisconsin.  Some of the storms pulsed to severe limits and generated large hail.  However, low-level south winds veered to west-southwest in the lowest 3 thousand feet of the atmosphere, allowing for the generation of low-level vorticity and an isolated tornado in central Racine County.

An upper level disturbance moved through West Tennessee during the morning of November 13th, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms developed in association with the disturbance. Some storms produced damaging winds and large hail.

An upper level disturbance moved through West Tennessee during the morning of November 13th, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms developed in association with the disturbance. Some storms produced damaging winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were knocked down on Sain Road, south of Bolivar, by straight line winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through West Tennessee during the afternoon hours of November 14, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms accompanied the front through the area. Some of the storms produced large hail and damaging winds.

A strong cold front moved through West Tennessee during the afternoon hours of November 14, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms accompanied the front through the area. Some of the storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds blew a roof off of a house near Gibson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through West Tennessee during the afternoon hours of November 14, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms accompanied the front through the area. Some of the storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Straight line winds blew trees down on North Main Street in Medina.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moved through North Mississippi during the afternoon hours of November 14, 2007. Showers and thunderstorms accompanied the front through the area. Some of the storms produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain produced flash flooding on County Road 614, outside of Corinth. Two vehicles were underwater as a result.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Short lines of severe thunderstorms moved east-northeast through south-central and southeast Wisconsin during the overnight hours.  Some cell movement exceeded 43 kts (50 mph) to the east.  Powerful downburst winds reached hurricane-force at 64 knots or higher (74 mph+), resulting in considerable tree and power-line damage.  Synoptically, a stationary front stretched from northern Iowa to northern Illinois.  Warm, moist, unstable air flowed north over the front in association with an upper-level short-wave trough, resulting in thunderstorm generation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck the roof of a church, started a fire, and damaged the church's sound system, computer system, and natural gas lines.  An automated fire-sprinkler system limited the amount of fire damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The July drought continued through the first two weeks of August, 2007, over parts of south-central and southeast Wisconsin.  The area was north of a line from Baraboo to Watertown to Mequon.  The corn, alfalfa, and soybean crops were affected, especially in the higher areas or well-drained or poor soils. It is unknown how much of a monetary loss the drought generated.  Thundestorm rains gradually reduced the effects of the drought by mid-month.  D1 (moderate) drought conditions were observed, which improved to D0 (abnormally dry) by the middle of August , 2007.

A cold front over northeast Iowa and northern Illinois combined with an unstable air mass to produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and  evening of June 21st.  The stronger storms produced damaging winds and large hail.  Heavy rain was also common with the storms, which caused some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed by strong thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over northeast Iowa and northern Illinois combined with an unstable air mass to produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and  evening of June 21st.  The stronger storms produced damaging winds and large hail.  Heavy rain was also common with the storms, which caused some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A roof of a mobile home was blown off.  It then struck another mobile home nearby.  Delayed report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over northeast Iowa and northern Illinois combined with an unstable air mass to produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and  evening of June 21st.  The stronger storms produced damaging winds and large hail.  Heavy rain was also common with the storms, which caused some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb 1.5 feet in diameter was downed over some power lines.  Power service was out in the Hershey Manor area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of showers and thunderstorm move across areas north of Highway 30 during the afternoon and evening hours of August 6th and the early morning hours of the 7th.  Heavy rains were widespread across these areas, with some isolated wind damage in Buchanan County.  Stephenson County Illinois was hardest hit with rainfall, where totals of three to seven inches fell, which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused power outages during the early morning hours of August 7th across parts of Jo Daviess County.  A transformer was damaged and needed to be replaced.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rains over the course of a week resulted in some river sites to not only reach their respective flood stage, but surpass the Major Flood stage level.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The river level at Oakland Mills went into flood during this period.  It crested at 21.18 feet on the evening of the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rains over the course of a week resulted in some river sites to not only reach their respective flood stage, but surpass the Major Flood stage level.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Des Moines River level at Keosauqua went into flood during this period.  It crested at 27.40 feet on the morning of the 24th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: November was yet another dry month for the Central Tennessee Valley.  Rainfall totals were generally between 2 and 3 inches areawide, except in a thin strip from Russellville to Courtland to North Huntsville to north of Scottsboro, where rainfall totals of 3 to 5 inches were realized.  These totals were still below normal areawide, however, so there was little relief to the ongoing historic drought.||Drought conditions were little changed during the month of November.  The only change occurred in the Shoals region, west of an Athens to Moulton line, where about a one category improvement in the U.S. Drought Monitor occurred between the end of October and the end of November.
Lightning struck homes in the Brownsburg and Fishers area as thunderstorms moved through the area during the early hours of November 11, 2007.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a house in Brownsburg during the early morning hours.  The lightning strike set the house on fire and blew out lighting figures and outlets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just after midnight on the 26th, a stationary front was located along a Hallock (MN) to Cooperstown (ND) to near Mobridge (SD) line. By 3 am CST, a weak surface low formed south of Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, and a cold front had moved to a Cavalier (ND) to Cooperstown (ND) to Ellendale (ND) line. By sunrise, the cold front had progressed east to a Warroad (MN) to Bagley (MN) to Fergus Falls (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed in the late evening of the 25th near the front south of Cooperstown, but around midnight CST, another thunderstorm complex developed over north central North Dakota. These storms took an east-northeast track, eventually crossing into northwest Minnesota several hours later.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the road.

Thunderstorms initially developed in the late evening of the 25th near the front south of Cooperstown, but around midnight CST, another thunderstorm complex developed over north central North Dakota. These storms took an east-northeast track, eventually crossing into northwest Minnesota several hours later.

A closed upper level low across West Texas and Eastern New Mexico moved slowly east into West-Central Texas on the 13th.  A short-wave trough in the base of the low tracked north-eastward across the Rio Grande Plains into the Coastal Plains of South Texas during the evening hours.  Large scale lift ahead of this feature spread across portions of Souh Texas during the afternoon, atop airmass that was moist and unstable.  Sufficient deep layer shear resulted in isolated severe storms during the afternoon across South Texas.  Evetually an organized MCS developed and swept across South Texas during the evening hours.  Southwesterly mid level winds of 40-50 kts atop a strenghtening low level jet in the evening across South Texas resulted in both bowing line segments and supercells.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly 2 inches of rain feel across Beeville resulting in flash flooding of Poesta Creek.  Later during the early morning of the 14th a motorist had to be rescued after driving around barricades and becoming stranded in the South Tyler St. low water crossing at Poesta Creek.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures just above the surface layer kept this thunderstorm event restricted to the area right along the border between northwest Minnesota and Canada. Early in the evening of the 24th, a cold front was located from Hallock, Minnesota, to near Bismarck, North Dakota. Over the next couple of hours, the front sagged a bit south, toward a Baudette, MN, to Grafton, ND, line. Thunderstorms initially developed over Kittson and Roseau Counties, but moved into southern Manitoba and southwest Ontario, Canada.

The drought raged on across much of the Central Tennessee Valley.  Huntsville International Airport (KHSV) recorded only four rain days in the entire month, for a total of just 1.26 inches.  Rainfall areawide ranged from just one inch at Russell Cave National Monument near Bridgeport (Jackson County) to over five inches in Valley Head (De Kalb County).  In northwest Alabama, two to five inches of rainfall benefited the short term drought conditions.  Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions which were areawide to begin the month improved to Extreme (D3) across this area, with even a sliver of far western Colbert and Franklin Counties improving to Severe (D2) category drought.  However, these improvements were largely short term in nature based on accounts from local drought officials.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Huntsville International Airport (KHSV) recorded only four rain days in the entire month, for a total of just 1.26 inches.  Rainfall areawide ranged from just one inch at Russell Cave National Monument near Bridgeport (Jackson County) to over five inches in Valley Head (De Kalb County).  In northwest Alabama, two to five inches of rainfall benefited the short term drought conditions.  Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions which were areawide to begin the month improved to Extreme (D3) across this area, with even a sliver of far western Colbert and Franklin Counties improving to Severe (D2) category drought.  However, these improvements were largely short term in nature based on accounts from local drought officials.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Humberto was the only hurricane to strike the U.S. coastline during the 2007 hurricane season.  The hurricane, which rapidly strenghted from a tropical storm off the upper Texas coast late on the 12th, moved inland near the Texas-Louisiana border early on the 13th.  The remnants of Hurricane Humberto then tracked across central Louisiana, central Mississippi, and into northern Alabama on the 14th.  The center of the remnant of the track moved across extreme northwest Georgia, Dade and Walker county, on the 14th.  With north Georgia being located within the favorable right quadrant of the track, much needed rainfall fell across north central and northwest parts of the state, mainly northwest of a Rome to Gainesville line.  Rainfall amounts of two to three inches were common within this area, with isolated five to six  inch rainfall amounts in parts of Whitfield and Murray counties.  Further south, rainfall amounts were generally one inch or less.  However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Humberto was the only hurricane to strike the U.S. coastline during the 2007 hurricane season. Rainfall amounts of two to three inches were common within this area, with isolated five to six  inch rainfall amounts in parts of Whitfield and Murray counties.  Further south, rainfall amounts were generally one inch or less.  However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms during the evening hours produced numerous tornadoes and large hail across the southern...central and eastern Texas panhandle. Heavy rains caused flash flooding in the eastern Texas panhandle during the late night and early morning hours. One man was killed by a tornado in the northeastern Texas panhandle and another person was injured.
