EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest flow aloft and a very warm, moist, and unstable lower atmosphere led to scattered afternoon and evening shower and thunderstorm development.  The strongest storms occurred in central sections of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Atlanta-Journal & Constitution reported that a 29-year old male was struck by lightning while doing construction work on a building in the Sandy Springs area.  Co-workers used a forklift to move him to the ground where he was treated by emergency medical technicians.  He was treated on site and then transported to a local hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest flow aloft and a very warm, moist, and unstable lower atmosphere led to scattered afternoon and evening shower and thunderstorm development.  The strongest storms occurred in central sections of the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Newton Citizen of Rockdale reported that lightning struck a home on Williams Road near Georgia Highway 81.  Extensive damage resulted to the attic.  The four occupants were displaced from their home.  Lightning also knocked out the power line to a home on Georgia Highway 142, but there was no fire reported that this site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first snow of the season moved into southwest Kansas during Friday, November 23rd and exited early Saturday, November 24th.  An upper level storm system moved out of southeastern Colorado Thursday night and by Friday morning was helping to draw moisture north from Oklahoma into southwestern Kansas.  This resulted in widespread light snow.  In general, 1 to 3 inches fell across the CWA.  The largest snowfall amount reported was 3.5 inches at Coldwater in Comanche County.   One 15 to 20 mile-wide band of 3 inches of snowfall fell from near Hugoton to northwest of Johnson.  Another swath 15 to 30 miles wide of 3-inch plus snowfall fell from Hays south through eastern Rush County and continued in the Larned, Kinsley and St. John areas.  One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The first snow of the season moved into southwest Kansas during Friday, November 23rd and exited early Saturday, November 24th.  An upper level storm system moved out of southeastern Colorado Thursday night and by Friday morning was helping to draw moisture north from Oklahoma into southwestern Kansas.  This resulted in widespread light snow.  In general, 1 to 3 inches fell across the CWA.  The largest snowfall amount reported was 3.5 inches at Coldwater in Comanche County.   One 15 to 20 mile-wide band of 3 inches of snowfall fell from near Hugoton to northwest of Johnson.  Another swath 15 to 30 miles wide of 3-inch plus snowfall fell from Hays south through eastern Rush County and continued in the Larned, Kinsley and St. John areas.  One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: June 25th proved to be one of the more significant severe weather days during the month.  This was the result of a strong short wave in westerly flow aloft and a very unstable and moist atmosphere present over the area.  Damaging downburst winds, large hail, and most significantly a number of lightning incidents were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jasper County 911 Center reported that three to four trees were down on Georgia Highway 83 near Shady Dale.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: June 25th proved to be one of the more significant severe weather days during the month.  This was the result of a strong short wave in westerly flow aloft and a very unstable and moist atmosphere present over the area.  Damaging downburst winds, large hail, and most significantly a number of lightning incidents were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Banks County 911 Center reported that three trees were down at three different locations between Lula and Homer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first snow of the season moved into southwest Kansas during Friday, November 23rd and exited early Saturday, November 24th.  An upper level storm system moved out of southeastern Colorado Thursday night and by Friday morning was helping to draw moisture north from Oklahoma into southwestern Kansas.  This resulted in widespread light snow.  In general, 1 to 3 inches fell across the CWA.  The largest snowfall amount reported was 3.5 inches at Coldwater in Comanche County.   One 15 to 20 mile-wide band of 3 inches of snowfall fell from near Hugoton to northwest of Johnson.  Another swath 15 to 30 miles wide of 3-inch plus snowfall fell from Hays south through eastern Rush County and continued in the Larned, Kinsley and St. John areas.  One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The first snow of the season moved into southwest Kansas during Friday, November 23rd and exited early Saturday, November 24th.  An upper level storm system moved out of southeastern Colorado Thursday night and by Friday morning was helping to draw moisture north from Oklahoma into southwestern Kansas.  This resulted in widespread light snow.  In general, 1 to 3 inches fell across the CWA.  The largest snowfall amount reported was 3.5 inches at Coldwater in Comanche County.   One 15 to 20 mile-wide band of 3 inches of snowfall fell from near Hugoton to northwest of Johnson. One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just after noon, a stationary front was located along a line from Rugby (ND) to Pembina (ND) to southwest Ontario, Canada. By late afternoon, the front had become a cold front and moved to a Devils Lake (ND) to Hallock (MN) to Flag Island (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed across extreme northeast North Dakota and extreme northwest Minnesota. These storms moved northeast and weakened over southwest Ontario.

The drought raged on across much of the Central Tennessee Valley.  Huntsville International Airport (KHSV) recorded only four rain days in the entire month, for a total of just 1.26 inches.  Rainfall areawide ranged from just one inch at Russell Cave National Monument near Bridgeport (Jackson County) to over five inches in Valley Head (De Kalb County).  In northwest Alabama, two to five inches of rainfall benefited the short term drought conditions.  Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions which were areawide to begin the month improved to Extreme (D3) across this area, with even a sliver of far western Colbert and Franklin Counties improving to Severe (D2) category drought.  However, these improvements were largely short term in nature based on accounts from local drought officials.

However, these improvements were largely short term in nature based on accounts from local drought officials.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog affected parts of east-central and southeast Wisconsin during the overnight hours and lowered visibilities to 1/8 to 1/4 mile. Several airplane flights were delayed or cancelled.  The dense fog was actually leftover dense fog that had persisted over the nearshore waters of Lake Michigan from the early morning hours of September 20th.  A light southeast wind during the daytime hours transported the leftover dense fog inland.  Clear skies and radiational cooling allowed the dense fog to expand as it moved inland.

An northwest flow of cold and unstable air aloft allowed scattered thunderstorms to develop and move southeast through southeastern Wisconsin.  Some of the storms pulsed to severe limits and generated large hail.  However, low-level south winds veered to west-southwest in the lowest 3 thousand feet of the atmosphere, allowing for the generation of low-level vorticity and an isolated tornado in central Racine County.

Short lines of severe thunderstorms moved east-northeast through south-central and southeast Wisconsin during the overnight hours.  Some cell movement exceeded 43 kts (50 mph) to the east.  Powerful downburst winds reached hurricane-force at 64 knots or higher (74 mph+), resulting in considerable tree and power-line damage.  Synoptically, a stationary front stretched from northern Iowa to northern Illinois.  Warm, moist, unstable air flowed north over the front in association with an upper-level short-wave trough, resulting in thunderstorm generation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerful thunderstorm wind gusts to 65 knots (75 mph) toppled many trees and damaged several power-lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over northeast Iowa and northern Illinois combined with an unstable air mass to produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and  evening of June 21st.  The stronger storms produced damaging winds and large hail.  Heavy rain was also common with the storms, which caused some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was struck by lightning splitting it in half.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A house was struck by lightning knocking the chimney off and causing some electrical wiring damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: East winds of 15 to 20 mph caused rip currents to form along the Palm Beach County coast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 49-year-old man was rescued from a rip current by a town of Palm Beach police officer. The victim was swimming about 100 feet from shore near Chilean Avenue and South Ocean Boulevard. The police officer was flagged down by a bystander and was in the water rescuing the victim when Fire-Rescue arrived at the scene.||The swimmer and the police officer were both taken to the hospital and were reported in good condition.

CZ_NAME: DEERFIELD BEACH TO OCEAN REEF FL
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waterspouts were observed off the Broward County coast in association with a line of showers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pilots reported waterspouts over the Broward County coastal waters from 1 to 4 miles east of Port Everglades. Movement of the waterspouts was not determined.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: November was yet another dry month for the Central Tennessee Valley.  Rainfall totals were generally between 2 and 3 inches areawide, except in a thin strip from Russellville to Courtland to North Huntsville to north of Scottsboro, where rainfall totals of 3 to 5 inches were realized.  These totals were still below normal areawide, however, so there was little relief to the ongoing historic drought.||Drought conditions were little changed during the month of November.  The only change occurred in the Shoals region, west of an Athens to Moulton line, where about a one category improvement in the U.S. Drought Monitor occurred between the end of October and the end of November.

A strong upper low moved over southern New Mexico and far west Texas from the southwest, with moist air being lifted over a cold low level easterly flow. The result was heavy snow over the southern Sacramento Mountains as well as at most elevations in far west Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts from 9 inches to nearly a foot were reported in the Cloudcroft area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper low moved over southern New Mexico and far west Texas from the southwest, with moist air being lifted over a cold low level easterly flow. The result was heavy snow over the southern Sacramento Mountains as well as at most elevations in far west Texas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow blanketed portions of El Paso. Four to six inches fell on the higher elevations of west El Paso, while six to seven inches accumulated over most of east and northeast El Paso. One location in the northeast part of the city at an elevation of near 5000 feet received ten inches of snow.

CZ_NAME: DEERFIELD BEACH TO OCEAN REEF FL
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of showers off the Miami-Dade County coast produced a waterspout just east of Key Biscayne.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pilot reported a waterspout just east of Key Biscayne. Showers in the area were nearly stationary.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low across West Texas and Eastern New Mexico moved slowly east into West-Central Texas on the 13th.  A short-wave trough in the base of the low tracked north-eastward across the Rio Grande Plains into the Coastal Plains of South Texas during the evening hours.  Large scale lift ahead of this feature spread across portions of Souh Texas during the afternoon, atop airmass that was moist and unstable.  Sufficient deep layer shear resulted in isolated severe storms during the afternoon across South Texas.  Evetually an organized MCS developed and swept across South Texas during the evening hours.  Southwesterly mid level winds of 40-50 kts atop a strenghtening low level jet in the evening across South Texas resulted in both bowing line segments and supercells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny sized hail reported in Cross.|

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the evening of the 17th, an area of surface low pressure was located just northeast of Jamestown, North Dakota, with a cold front extending south from the low. A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.

Warm temperatures just above the surface layer kept this thunderstorm event restricted to the area right along the border between northwest Minnesota and Canada. Early in the evening of the 24th, a cold front was located from Hallock, Minnesota, to near Bismarck, North Dakota. Over the next couple of hours, the front sagged a bit south, toward a Baudette, MN, to Grafton, ND, line. Thunderstorms initially developed over Kittson and Roseau Counties, but moved into southern Manitoba and southwest Ontario, Canada.

Thunderstorms initially developed over Kittson and Roseau Counties, but moved into southern Manitoba and southwest Ontario, Canada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged in size from dime to hen egg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was spotted during the early afternoon in the Mooresville, AL vicinity.  The funnel was photographed by from at least two vantage points and was visually seen by a pilot from an incoming commercial aircraft into Huntsville International Airport.  The photographic evidence showed a condensation funnel that was not quite half way down from cloud base and no damage was reported.  Analysis of local Doppler radar data and near storm environmental conditions revealed that this funnel was most likely generated through a process that generates landspouts, or non-supercell tornadoes.  A towering cumulus cloud had developed in this area, followed almost immediately by the funnel cloud report.  A thunderstorm cluster moved northeast and entered the area soonafter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A funnel cloud was observed in the Mooresville, AL vicinity.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced strong winds and small hail over Marshall County in northeast Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down by thunderstorm winds on Preston Island.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two fatalities resulted from this heat wave in Morgan County, Alabama.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 59 year old female of Decatur passed away on the 15th.  The woman was found in her residence where the temperature exceeded 100 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low moved from southern California eastward across the desert southwest, with southerly flow tapping abundant subtropical moisture in advance of the system. Cold low level flow did not push southward into far west TX as strongly as anticipated, so an areawide heavy snow and ice storm episode did not materialize. However, while the majority of the area experienced heavy rain, significant ice accumulated in northeastern Hudspeth County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Much of northeastern Hudspeth County, including Cornudas was covered by at least 1/4 inch of ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second storm in 4 days, this one weaker and not as moist but much colder, dropped southeastward into southern NM and far west TX. Much more snow fell out of this storm than the preceding one. Interstate 25 north of Radium Springs and Interstate 10 west of Lordsburg were closed, as were several highways in southern and southwestern NM.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totalled 8 inches in Hillsboro and Truth or Consequences, where travelers on Interstate 25 were sheltered.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Humberto was the only hurricane to strike the U.S. coastline during the 2007 hurricane season.  The hurricane, which rapidly strenghted from a tropical storm off the upper Texas coast late on the 12th, moved inland near the Texas-Louisiana border early on the 13th.  The remnants of Hurricane Humberto then tracked across central Louisiana, central Mississippi, and into northern Alabama on the 14th.  The center of the remnant of the track moved across extreme northwest Georgia, Dade and Walker county, on the 14th.  With north Georgia being located within the favorable right quadrant of the track, much needed rainfall fell across north central and northwest parts of the state, mainly northwest of a Rome to Gainesville line.  Rainfall amounts of two to three inches were common within this area, with isolated five to six  inch rainfall amounts in parts of Whitfield and Murray counties.  Further south, rainfall amounts were generally one inch or less.  However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms during the evening hours produced numerous tornadoes and large hail across the southern...central and eastern Texas panhandle. Heavy rains caused flash flooding in the eastern Texas panhandle during the late night and early morning hours. One man was killed by a tornado in the northeastern Texas panhandle and another person was injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front sagged south across the state during the previous night and became stationary east-west over far southern Iowa.  The airmass became very unstable during the afternoon as temperatures soared into the low to mid 90s.  Dew points pooled over southwest into west central Iowa and were in the upper 70s to low 80s across the area.  This lead to CAPE values in excess of 7000 J/kg and a lifted index of -12 C.  Needless to say, considerable moisture was available with precipitable water values in the 2 to 2.25 inch range.  Thunderstorms developed over Nebraska and moved into Iowa during the afternoon.  A strong bow echo developed and advanced east-southeast across the west central, then across the south west into the south central counties of the state.  Some of the storms produced hail, but the hail was below severe levels.  In spite of the available cape in the -10 to -30 C. layer of the atmosphere being in the 600 to 900 J/kg range, hail was suppressed once again by the high freezing levels.  Freezing levels were between 14,500 and 15,000 feet.  The LCL was a relatively low 750 to 1000 meters, however downdraft CAPE was very high, between 1200 and 1600 J/kg.  Winds dominated the event as the storms advanced rapidly eastward in a shear environment of 40 to 50 kts.  There were numerous reports of trees toppled and power line damage.  Wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH were common.  Some of the higher gusts came from the Adair area.  Mesonet sites reported wind gusts of 66 to 71 MPH in the area.

However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hurricane Humberto was the only hurricane to strike the U.S. coastline during the 2007 hurricane season.  The hurricane, which rapidly strenghted from a tropical storm off the upper Texas coast late on the 12th, moved inland near the Texas-Louisiana border early on the 13th.  The remnants of Hurricane Humberto then tracked across central Louisiana, central Mississippi, and into northern Alabama on the 14th.  The center of the remnant of the track moved across extreme northwest Georgia, Dade and Walker county, on the 14th.  With north Georgia being located within the favorable right quadrant of the track, much needed rainfall fell across north central and northwest parts of the state, mainly northwest of a Rome to Gainesville line.  Rainfall amounts of two to three inches were common within this area, with isolated five to six  inch rainfall amounts in parts of Whitfield and Murray counties.  Further south, rainfall amounts were generally one inch or less.  However, afternoon heating combined with the final feeder band associated with Humberto to bring a line of heavy showers and thunderstorms to north Georgia during the afternoon.  A few trees were blown down and there were a couple of reports of hail.  However, no significant damage was reported within Georgia as a result of the remnants of Humberto.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first snow of the season moved into southwest Kansas during Friday, November 23rd and exited early Saturday, November 24th.  An upper level storm system moved out of southeastern Colorado Thursday night and by Friday morning was helping to draw moisture north from Oklahoma into southwestern Kansas.  This resulted in widespread light snow.  In general, 1 to 3 inches fell across the CWA.  The largest snowfall amount reported was 3.5 inches at Coldwater in Comanche County.   One 15 to 20 mile-wide band of 3 inches of snowfall fell from near Hugoton to northwest of Johnson.  Another swath 15 to 30 miles wide of 3-inch plus snowfall fell from Hays south through eastern Rush County and continued in the Larned, Kinsley and St. John areas.  One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.

Another swath 15 to 30 miles wide of 3-inch plus snowfall fell from Hays south through eastern Rush County and continued in the Larned, Kinsley and St. John areas.  One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another record breaking snow event for west Texas and southeastern New Mexico as an upper level storm system and a cold front move across the region.  Six to eight inches of snow in the Van Horn area resulted in Interstate 10 being closed between Fort Hancock and Fort Stockton and Interstate 20 being closed between Pecos and Fort Hancock.  At least 200 tractor trailers were stranded in Van Horn and Pecos when those interstates closed.  Schools across west Texas and southeastern New Mexico closed for at least a day.  Locations across the region received anywhere from an inch to eleven inches of snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 166 became impossible to drive on.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a dry month of May, the heat and dry weather in June caused drought conditions to develop and intensify into the D2 classification for a portion of the western lowland counties.  Rain fed crops were struggling to mature. Much needed rain did fall during the last week of the month.

The drought raged on across much of the Central Tennessee Valley.  Huntsville International Airport (KHSV) recorded only four rain days in the entire month, for a total of just 1.26 inches.  Rainfall areawide ranged from just one inch at Russell Cave National Monument near Bridgeport (Jackson County) to over five inches in Valley Head (De Kalb County).  In northwest Alabama, two to five inches of rainfall benefited the short term drought conditions.  Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions which were areawide to begin the month improved to Extreme (D3) across this area, with even a sliver of far western Colbert and Franklin Counties improving to Severe (D2) category drought.  However, these improvements were largely short term in nature based on accounts from local drought officials.

However, these improvements were largely short term in nature based on accounts from local drought officials.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the first big snow event of the winter season, and it was a Colorado Low. These are traditionally bigger snow producers for the northern plains than Alberta Clippers or hybrid low pressure systems. This system was no exception, as it dropped from 6 to 11 inches of snow over southeast North Dakota and portions of west central and northwest Minnesota. Wind speeds never became gusty, but the with warm ground temperatures, surfaces did become slick. The highest snow total, 11 inches, occurred at Wadena, Minnesota. This event continued through December 2nd.
A winter storm moved from the southern Plains toward the Great Lakes during the early morning hours of December 11. A mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain affected portions of northeast Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain caused a glazing of two-tenths of an inch of ice.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air surged into Northern Michigan, bringing gusty winds and light accumulations of lake effect snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blustery winds gusting off of Lake Michigan brought down a few trees and power lines.  Motorists in four vehicles were trapped in their cars for nearly two hours, when power lines came down across M-22 south of Leland (just south of M-204).  A summer home on the west shore of Lake Leelanau was destroyed by a fire ignited by downed power lines (indirect damage).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Exceptional Drought (D4) conditions remained throughout September.  Rainfall for the month ranged from around one half inch up to two and a quarter inches, or about 2 to 4 inches below normal.  Winchester received 2.17 inches and Sewanee received 2.24 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved through South Central Texas during the evening of November 21 after a record high was recorded in San Antonio. Below normal temperatures were observed the next two days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A man was found dead outdoors and his death was ruled to be probable hypothermia. His body was shirtless and shoeless when it was discovered. The low temperature that morning was 42 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into east central Iowa and northwest Illinois during the afternoon hours of June 27th igniting a line of heavy rain-producing thunderstorms.  Rainfall totals averaged between 1.50 and 2.25 inches.  Some of the storms also produced hail up to the size of a nickel.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime size hail accompanied a line of thunderstorms as they moved southeast across Carroll County.  Very heavy rain was also noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front over northeast Iowa and northern Illinois combined with an unstable air mass to produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and  evening of June 21st.  The stronger storms produced damaging winds and large hail.  Heavy rain was also common with the storms, which caused some flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail fell in North English.

CZ_NAME: DEERFIELD BEACH TO OCEAN REEF FL
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waterspouts were observed off the Broward County coast in association with a line of showers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pilot reported multiple waterspouts over the Broward County coastal waters about 10 miles east-northeast of Fort Lauderdale International Airport. Movement was unknown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Drought conditions continued over most of the interior and southwest sections of South Florida during December. Below normal rainfall during the month, in combination with record low levels of Lake Okeechobee, led to worsening drought conditions over Glades County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe drought conditions (D2) continued over most of the interior and southwest sections of South Florida during December. Below normal rainfall going back to November has led to lowering of water levels, with some areas reporting levels at less than 10 percent of normal. Lake Okeechobee continued to set daily record low levels of just over 10 feet. Glades County was placed in an extreme drought condition (D3) during the second week of December due to very dry ground conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist easterly flow due to high pressure over the four corners combined with daytime heating to cause severe thunderstorms with strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately 100 trees were uprooted and knocked down at Oro Valley Country Club on Greenock Road due to a wet microburst.  An additional 30 trees were uprooted at a nearby shopping plaza at Oracle Road and 1st Avenue.  The uprooted trees caused roof damage to several houses.  The storms also blew off part of a roof at the Blue Moon stables in Oro Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant monsoonal moisture caused numerous thunderstorms across much of Southeast Arizona.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm near Safford produced a strong outflow resulting in a dust storm. The visibility dropped to about 100 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A closed upper level low across West Texas and Eastern New Mexico moved slowly east into West-Central Texas on the 13th.  A short-wave trough in the base of the low tracked north-eastward across the Rio Grande Plains into the Coastal Plains of South Texas during the evening hours.  Large scale lift ahead of this feature spread across portions of Souh Texas during the afternoon, atop airmass that was moist and unstable.  Sufficient deep layer shear resulted in isolated severe storms during the afternoon across South Texas.  Evetually an organized MCS developed and swept across South Texas during the evening hours.  Southwesterly mid level winds of 40-50 kts atop a strenghtening low level jet in the evening across South Texas resulted in both bowing line segments and supercells.

A short-wave trough in the base of the low tracked north-eastward across the Rio Grande Plains into the Coastal Plains of South Texas during the evening hours.  Large scale lift ahead of this feature spread across portions of Souh Texas during the afternoon, atop airmass that was moist and unstable.  Sufficient deep layer shear resulted in isolated severe storms during the afternoon across South Texas.  Evetually an organized MCS developed and swept across South Texas during the evening hours.  Southwesterly mid level winds of 40-50 kts atop a strenghtening low level jet in the evening across South Texas resulted in both bowing line segments and supercells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golfball sized hail was reported 10 miles souhtwest of Goliad, on U.S. 59.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved northeast through southern Wisconsin.  Short segments of the line managed to bow out and generate isolated downbursts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerful thunderstorm downburst winds gusting to an estimated 56 knots (65 mph) toppled several large trees.  Tree branch debris knocked down some power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved northeast through southern Wisconsin.  Short segments of the line managed to bow out and generate isolated downbursts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerful thunderstorm downburst winds gusting to an estimated 65 knots (75 mph) toppled several large trees.  Tree branch debris knocked down some power lines.  The winds lifted one side of a trained spotters's vehicle about 6 inches into the air.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dense fog developed during the early morning hours between Port Washington and Racine thanks to clear skies, radiational cooling, and a light northeast-east wind off of the still relatively warm waters of Lake Michigan.  Visibilities were reduced to 1/8 to 1/4 mile.  Several airplane flights were delayed or cancelled.

Late in the evening of the 17th, an area of surface low pressure was located just northeast of Jamestown, North Dakota, with a cold front extending south from the low. A warm front arched to the northeast, from near Jamestown to Grand Forks to Bemidji (MN). From the surface through the low layers of the atmosphere, wind speeds were quite strong. In the late afternoon of the 17th, one lone thunderstorm cell developed over Polk County (MN). By early evening, another lone thunderstorm developed over Ramsey County (ND). Finally, just before midnight, a line of thunderstorms took shape over eastern North Dakota. This line of storms moved into northwest Minnesota around midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Metal roofing was pulled off a bank building, which caused water damage inside. Trees were blown down in town too.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many large trees were snapped off or uprooted. A metal storage shed full of furnature was blown across a yard. Truck loading equipment was blown down at the fertilizer plant.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: At Lake Maud, strong winds damaged a cabin roof and uprooted many trees. Some trees fell on lake cabins.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Just after midnight on the 26th, a stationary front was located along a Hallock (MN) to Cooperstown (ND) to near Mobridge (SD) line. By 3 am CST, a weak surface low formed south of Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, and a cold front had moved to a Cavalier (ND) to Cooperstown (ND) to Ellendale (ND) line. By sunrise, the cold front had progressed east to a Warroad (MN) to Bagley (MN) to Fergus Falls (MN) line. Thunderstorms initially developed in the late evening of the 25th near the front south of Cooperstown, but around midnight CST, another thunderstorm complex developed over north central North Dakota. These storms took an east-northeast track, eventually crossing into northwest Minnesota several hours later.

The second storm in 4 days, this one weaker and not as moist but much colder, dropped southeastward into southern NM and far west TX. Much more snow fell out of this storm than the preceding one. Interstate 25 north of Radium Springs and Interstate 10 west of Lordsburg were closed, as were several highways in southern and southwestern NM.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts included 4 inches in Lordsburg and 6 inches in Animas (both are desert locations). Interstate 10 was closed west of Lordsburg.

Much more snow fell out of this storm than the preceding one. Interstate 25 north of Radium Springs and Interstate 10 west of Lordsburg were closed, as were several highways in southern and southwestern NM.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: From 8 to 12 inches of snow fell in Cloudcroft, with 8 inches blanketing Mayhill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The second storm in 4 days, this one weaker and not as moist but much colder, dropped southeastward into southern NM and far west TX. Much more snow fell out of this storm than the preceding one. Interstate 10 in Hudspeth County was closed, as were several highways in the area mainly east of El Paso.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 6 inches in the far southeastern portion of El Paso County, including Fabens.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts ranged from 4 inches in the northwest corner of Hudspeth County to 8 inches on Interstate 10 near the Culberson County line. Interstate 10 was closed in most of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line moved through the Middle Texas Coast
